componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Equinix Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If anyone has objections, please disconnect at this time. I'd now like to turn the call over to Katrina Rymill, Vice President of Investor Relations. Thank you, and you may begin.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to today's conference call. Before we get started, I would like to remind everyone that some of the statements we'll be making today are forward-looking in nature and involve risks and uncertainties. Actual results may vary sig
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to today's conference call. Before we get started, I would like to remind everyone that some of the statements we'll be making today are forward-looking in nature and involve risks and uncertainties. Actual results may vary significantly from those statements and may be affected by the risks we identified in today's press release and those identified in our filings with the SEC, including our most recent Form 10-Q filed on October 30, 2015.
Equinix assumes no obligation and does not intend to update or comment on forward-looking statements made on this call. In addition, in light of regulation fair disclosure, it's Equinix's policy not to comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it is done through an explicit public disclosure. 
In addition, we'll provide non-GAAP measures on today's conference call. We'll provide a reconciliation of those measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures and a list of the reasons why the company uses these measures in today's press release on the Equinix Investor Relations page at www.equinix.com. 
We would also like to remind you that we post important information about Equinix on the IR page of our website. We encourage you to check our website regularly for the most current available information. With us today are Steve Smith, Equinix's CEO and President; Keith Taylor, Chief Financial Officer; and Charles Meyers, Chief Operating Officer. Following our prepared remarks, we'll be taking questions from sell-side analysts. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'll turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Katrina, and good afternoon, and welcome to our fourth quarter earnings call. 2015 was a transformational year for Equinix. We delivered accelerated growth, expanded our global platform with 2 strategic acquisitions, completed our first y
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Katrina, and good afternoon, and welcome to our fourth quarter earnings call. 2015 was a transformational year for Equinix. We delivered accelerated growth, expanded our global platform with 2 strategic acquisitions, completed our first year operating as a REIT and established ourselves as a foundation for the cloud ecosystem that continues to drive IT transformation. 
Our strong financial performance reflects our position as the global leader in retail co-location and interconnection, truly serving as the place where opportunity connects for leading networks, clouds, content providers and enterprises. We continue to extend our market-leading network density attracting wireline, wireless and increasingly, subsea carriers who are using Platform Equinix to efficiently interconnect and serve their end customers. 
Our data centers act as a powerful commerce center for the largest service providers to reach their customers and are positioning us to capture the enterprise as they implement next-generation IT architectures. We will further leverage our leadership position through the integration of Telecity and Bit-isle and scale the business to drive even more value for our combined customers. 
Before I turn to the quarterly results, I'd like to reflect on a few of the meaningful milestones we achieved in 2015. Starting with financial performance on Slide 3. With another year of record bookings activity in 2015, we generated over $2.7 billion of revenue, up 16% year-over-year on a normalized and constant currency basis. We delivered over $1.27 billion of adjusted EBITDA or a 47% margin, an over 100 basis point improvement over last year while continuing to invest in the business. This drove AFFO growth of 25% on a normalized and constant currency basis, exceeding our prior guidance after adjusting for the Telecity transaction-related FX loss. 
Second, it was a phenomenal year for our interconnection solutions. Interconnection revenue continues to outpace overall revenue, growing 20% year-over-year on a constant currency organic basis. With over 171,000 cross connects, 3,300 ports on our Internet exchange and dramatic growth on our Cloud Exchange, we are benefiting from the strong secular trends that are driving businesses to become increasingly interconnected. 
Third, we significantly expanded our global platform both organically and inorganically. Equinix completed 20 major IBX expansions in 2015, creating the needed capacity to support strong fill rates in high demand markets. 
Overall, our development activity continues to generate highly attractive returns and healthy yield on our sizable base of stabilized assets. With the Telecity and Bit-isle acquisitions, we further expanded Platform Equinix, which now spans 145 data centers across 40 metros and 21 countries. Combined, Equinix now operates over 14 million gross square feet of co-location space, enhancing our position as the largest retail data center footprint in the world.
Fourth, we continue to establish Equinix as the home of the interconnected cloud, which in turn is attracting enterprises that are adopting hybrid and multi-cloud as their IT architecture of choice. Key cloud customers, including Amazon, Cisco, IBM, Microsoft and Oracle, to mention a few, are all using Equinix to scale their infrastructure globally and are now deployed across an average of 17 markets. 
And finally, we successfully completed our first year operating as a REIT and returned $394 million back to our shareholders. We were included in the S&P 500, the MSCI RMZ and the FTSE NAREIT indices, reflection of our position as both a technology leader and as the largest data center REIT. We continue to strengthen our balance sheet, raising $2.6 billion in debt and equity in the fourth quarter, fortifying our capital structure while providing a strong liquidity position.
Now turning to the quarter. We had a great finish to the year, delivering record bookings in the fourth quarter with particular strength in the Americas and robust metrics, including our highest-ever interconnection activity and very firm yield per cabinet. We continue to take market share, capture an outsized portion of the new infrastructure deployments from both clouds and enterprises. 
The quality and scale of our wins continues to increase, and we are proud that over 140 of the Fortune 500 are Equinix customers. Our geographic reach remains critical to customers, with over 55% of our revenue coming from customers deployed globally across all 3 regions and over 84% from customers deployed across multiple metros.
Our global platform is increasingly defensible, durable and hard to replicate with regards to reach and capacity as well as performance. With the addition of the Telecity and Bit-isle acquisitions, we added 40 data centers and 1,100 people across Europe and Japan. This scale positions us well to build market leadership, increase capacity, enhanced cloud and network density and grow customer ecosystems for years to come. 
With Telecity, we've added 7 new metro markets to our portfolio, creating a large opportunity for current Equinix customers to expand further north and east across EMEA. Additionally, there are over 500 customers of former Telecity that have business presence in another country where Platform Equinix resides, creating a potential for powerful cross-selling opportunities as we integrate. We are confident both these transactions will drive significant long-term value creation for our customers and our partners.
Now let me cover quarterly highlights from our industry verticals. Starting with the network vertical. This customer base continues to grow as we enhance ecosystems in which networks and mobile providers can participate and grow their businesses. Strong global bandwidth demand is driving a resurgence of subsea cable projects, creating new opportunities for Equinix. These service providers are accelerating returns by terminating cables directly into our IBXs where they can further benefit by gaining access to key business ecosystems. 
In the content digital media vertical, content customers are expanding across our global platform to meet the continued explosion of consumer demand for digital content and applications. The advertising subsegment remains the fastest growth driver in this vertical as digital advertising takes share from traditional channels. 
Customers expanding this quarter include AppNexus, which optimizes programmatic digital advertising; AudienceScience, a global advertising technology and services company; and Criteo, a French company specializing in performance marketing. 
Turning to the financial services vertical. In addition to our strong electronic trading ecosystem, we continue to diversify across subsegments, including insurance, wealth management and banking, which contributed to record bookings for the quarter. New wins include a top 20 private wealth management firm initiating a multi-cloud strategy to speed to market; a Fortune 500 asset management company that is connecting to clouds over our Equinix Cloud Exchange; and a partner-led deal with a top 10 insurance firm based in Europe.
In cloud and IT services, the cloud ecosystem delivered strong growth this quarter, driven by key Infrastructure-as-a-Service providers such as AWS and Microsoft as well as momentum with Software-as-a-Service providers who represent the fastest-growing subsegment of this vertical. SaaS customer expansions include ServiceNow, an IT service management provider; and Shape Security, an advanced application defense provider that offers security services for cloud exchange clients. We continue to see momentum on our Cloud Exchange and have over 300 enterprises clouds, IT service providers and networks interconnecting using our solution.
Turning to the enterprise. The enterprise vertical delivered strong bookings as businesses seek to re-architect IT to adapt rapidly changing business requirements. By leveraging an interconnection-oriented architecture, enterprises can address multiple IT challenges and solve for the cost, scaling and performance needs of today's digital world. 
For the second quarter, enterprise was the largest source of new customer adds, with particular traction in manufacturing and Professional Services. New wins include Polo Ralph Laurent, a premium clothing and lifestyle brand; Granite Construction, an S&P 500 civil general contractor and construction material producer; and Cosmetics, a Swedish cosmetic manufacturer. 
Over 300 customers have deployed our Performance Hub solution, which is an extremely attractive entry point for enterprise customers who seek to optimize network architectures and also access the cloud and drive application performance. And we are already enjoying significant upsell in cross-sell traction with these customers. So let me stop here and turn it over to Keith to cover some more specifics for the quarter.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good afternoon to everyone on the call. Let me start by saying from so many points of view, Q4 was the best quarter we have experienced to date. The momentum in our organic business, combined with Telecity and Bit-isle, sets us up nicel
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good afternoon to everyone on the call. Let me start by saying from so many points of view, Q4 was the best quarter we have experienced to date. The momentum in our organic business, combined with Telecity and Bit-isle, sets us up nicely for 2016 as well as our initial look through into 2017. 
And with my prepared remarks, I'll first review our full year 2015 results then I'll provide some commentary on key metrics for '16, which have a number of moving parts. Finally, I'll wrap up with some high-level comments on the fourth quarter.
So starting with revenues. We reported revenues of over $2.72 billion for 2015, a 16% year-over-year normalized and constant currency growth rate, a clear demonstration of our ability to drive outsized growth as we benefit from the scale of our global platform as well as enjoy record nonrecurring revenue activity. And we believe this momentum will continue into 2016. 
We expect to deliver normalized and constant currency growth of greater than 13% for our organic business and over $540 million of revenues from Telecity and Bit-isle at current exchange rates. We believe the Telecity business, net of the expected divestitures, will grow revenues between 8% and 9% in 2016, while Bit-isle's revenues will remain essentially flat year-over-year, consistent with our expectations while we look to optimize this business over the next 24 months.
In 2015, we improved our organic adjusted EBITDA margin by over 100 basis points to 46.7%. And as we continue to scale the business, we expect to deliver another 100 basis points of improvement on the organic business in 2016 as we maintain disciplined and focused on our spending initiatives. 
Another key driver to our continued margin improvement is the healthy price yield derived from a disciplined pricing initiative and strong interconnection activity. For 2016, we expect our consolidated adjusted EBITDA margins to be greater than 47.3%, excluding integration costs or 45.6% on an as-reported basis.
Our 2015 pro forma AFFO, which excludes the impact of the Telecity FX losses and the integration costs, was $905 million, significantly higher than expected for the year. Looking forward on a normalized and constant currency basis, 2016 AFFO is expected to grow greater than 23% over the prior year.
With respect to the Telecity and Bit-isle acquisitions, we're very excited about these acquisitions and the ability to strengthen our market position. That said, I want to highlight a few areas recognizing we'll be incurring some costs that won't be part of the ongoing business, thereby allowing you to better understand the combined business on a go-forward basis. 
So let me start with FX. We elected to hedge the cash portion of the Telecity purchase price. In effect, we locked in the dollar value of this sizable deal. This resulted in an FX loss of $61 million in 2015, with $49 million of the loss being recognized in Q4. These losses impacted our AFFO metric for both Q3 and Q4 and for the year. 
For Q1, as we completed the purchase of the Telecity acquisition, we experienced an incremental $50 million loss in the quarter. Again, this loss will impact our Q1 and 2016 AFFO metric. Finally, it's important to note that the offset to the Telecity FX losses is a corresponding reduction to the purchase price of Telecity. 
For both Telecity and Bit-isle, we've begun the integration process to combined the teams, the organizations and the systems together. We expect to incur $58 million in integration costs in 2016, as anticipated in our investment models, with an approximate $20 million of additional integration costs being spent in 2017.
These costs support systems work, of significance, employees costs, including severance and retention and substantial organizational restructuring in support of our REIT and other tax initiatives. We expect incremental revenue, cost and CapEx synergies from the acquisitions from Telecity and Bit-isle as we integrate these businesses. 
Our current revenue guidance contemplates modest revenue synergy assumptions this year, which we expect to ramp up over time as both Equinix and Telecity customers leverage the expanded footprint service portfolio and rich ecosystems of the combined company. As we progress with our integration efforts, we also expect to achieve $30 million in annual cost savings, with about 50% of these savings being realized before the end of this year and the rest coming in 2017.
For CapEx synergies, the available Bit-isle inventory has positioned us well in the Tokyo market, allowing us to defer significant capital spend to other projects, while the Telecity capacity in our overlapping markets allows us to free up capital to be deployed in other markets, both in Europe and across the platform.
And as previously announced, we need to divest 8 assets from the combined Equinix Telecity EMEA business, with a target divestiture date of mid-2016. In light of the current momentum in the business and the size of the market opportunity in front of us, it is our intention to reinvest the divestiture proceeds back into the business. We currently believe this is the highest and best use of our capital. We believe this allows us to maximize both our short- and longer-term shareholder value objectives while driving -- I'm sorry, while providing us the strategic and operational flexibility we've historically enjoyed, particularly during volatile times. And these proceeds, along with capital raised in November, should allow us to self-fund the business for the foreseeable future despite our increased expansion activities and anticipated growing cash dividend.
From an AFFO perspective, the value of these acquisitions and our AFFO generating potential is better than our original assumptions. With a view towards 2017, we expect these acquisitions on a combined basis to be accretive to Equinix's AFFO per share for the 2017 reporting year excluding the integration costs. 
So turning to the fourth quarter. It was another terrific quarter at Equinix. Our strategy continues to deliver better-than-expected results across the company. At the global level, we had record gross and net bookings, with particular strength in the financial services and enterprise verticals. Our interconnection metrics were again outstanding as we added 7,500 cross connects and 162 exchange ports this quarter. Our MRR per cab on an FX-neutral basis was very firm, and we remain well positioned across each of our operating regions.
As depicted on Slide 4, global Q4 revenues were $730.5 million, our 52nd consecutive quarter of top line revenue growth, up 4% quarter-over-quarter and 17% over the same quarter last year on a normalized and constant currency basis. Our as-reported revenues include $21.6 million of Bit-isle revenue from November and December, consistent with our expectations and the investment model. 
Q4 organic revenue, net of our FX hedges, absorbs an $8 million negative currency impact when compared to the average FX rates used last quarter and a $4 million negative currency impact when compared to our FX guidance rates. Currency, volatility against the majority of our key operating currencies continue to cause significant FX headwinds. For 2016, the strength in U.S. dollar creates a $51 million FX headwind against revenues and a $29 million headwind against adjusted EBITDA for our organic business when compared to the average FX raised -- rates used in 2015.
For Europe, we've hedged over 85% of our Equinix organic business. Given the growth of the international businesses, including Telecity and Bit-isle acquisitions, we expect our revenue mix to shift such as greater than 50% of our revenues will be generated from outside the U.S.
Global adjusted EBITDA was $333.1 million, up 4% over the prior quarter and 20% over the same quarter last year on a normalized and constant currency basis. Our normalized adjusted EBITDA margin was 46.4% and includes $2.8 million in integration costs. Our Q4 organic adjusted EBITDA performance, net of our FX hedges, reflects a negative $5.4 million currency impact when compared to the average FX rates last quarter and a $1.2 million negative impact when compared to our guidance rates.
Global AFFO was $178 million. Excluding the Telecity foreign currency loss and acquisition-related costs, AFFO on a normalized and constant currency basis increased 4% over the prior quarter, above the top end of our guidance range by $13 million, largely due to lower-than-expected cash taxes. 
And finally, moving to churn. Total MRR churn for Q4 was 2.3%, consistent with our prior guidance and weighted towards the end of the quarter. For 2016, we expect our quarterly MRR churn to remain in our targeted 2% to 2.5% quarterly range. 
I'd like to provide some highlights on the regions, whose full results are covered on Slides 5 to 7. All 3 regions delivered better-than-expected revenues, with EMEA and Asia Pacific showing normalized and constant currency growth of 20% and 25% respectively, while the Americas region produced growth of 13% on its much larger base. 
The Americas region had a great quarter, delivering record bookings driven by the financial and enterprise verticals, very firm yield per cabinet and the best interconnection quarter of all time. EMEA delivered another strong quarter of bookings, with particular strength in our French and German markets, while Asia Pacific continued its rapid growth as customers deployed across the region with gross bookings driven by cloud and IT services, enterprise and network verticals.
Interconnection revenues continued to outpace overall growth of the business, with the Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific interconnection revenues now at 22%, 10% and 13%, respectively, of the recurring revenues.
And now looking at the balance sheet, please refer to Slide 8. Unrestricted cash and investments increased this quarter to $2.2 billion due to the successful financings in November on a restricted cash balances totaled $490 million, largely due to the escrow funds related to the Telecity deal. 
Our year-end net debt leverage ratio was 3.2x at Q4 and annualized adjusted EBITDA although steps up to greater than 4x after funding the cash portion of the Telecity transaction. Given the favorable cash flow attributes of the business model, we expect the Equinix calculated leverage ratio to return to the higher end of our targeted 3x to 4x adjusted EBITDA over the next 12 to 18 months.
Now switching to AFFO and dividends on Slide 9. For 2016, we expect our as-reported AFFO to be greater than $970 million, a 17% year-over-year increase. On a normalized and constant currency basis, AFFO would be greater than $1.078 billion or a 23% increase over the prior year.
Turning to dividends. Today, we announced our Q1 dividend of $1.75 a share, a 3.6% increase over the prior cash dividend per share. For 2016, our projected total cash dividends to be paid will increase to approximately $500 million, a 27% increase over the prior year. Our normalized AFFO payout ratio will approximate 52% in 2016. 
Our estimated share count for 2016 approximate 70.5 million shares, including 6.9 million shares issued to Telecity shareholders and 1.96 million shares expected to be issued in June 2016 to our convertible debt holders.
We continue to believe that both organic and inorganic growth will be the primary ingredient for a steadily growing cash dividend. And we've maintained the flexibility to move additional entities from the taxable REIT structure to the qualified REIT structure over time. 
Now looking at capital expenditures, please refer to Slide 10. For the quarter, our capital expenditures were $281 million, including recurring CapEx of $45 million, slightly higher than guidance due to the timing of cash payments to our contractors. We now have 14 [ph] expansion projects underway. 
For 2016, we expect 95% of expansion capital to be allocated to campus or existing market builds and 5% for new market development. Given the strong performance at our key markets, we expect to move forward with additional expansion phases in Ashburn, Frankfurt, Hong Kong, Silicon Valley and a new flagship build in the Amsterdam Science Park, an interconnection hub. 
Also, given our high utilization rate of 81% and increasing as well as strong development returns, we expect 2016 CapEx to range between $900 million and $1 billion, which contemplates several new first phase IBX builds on our core Equinix owned campuses, including Ashburn and Silicon Valley as well as a number of non-U.S. campuses. 
And finally, we've provided you a number of slides that bridge the normalized 2015 performance to our 2016 guidance, including slides for revenue and adjusted EBITDA. Please refer to Slides 13 to 17. These slides also include the contributions from Telecity and Bit-isle acquisitions.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Keith. Let me now cover our 2016 strategy on Slide 12. Our strategic priorities remain centered on driving growth by pressing our competitive advantage and investing to capture significant opportunities, such as the cloud-enabled enterprise.
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Keith. Let me now cover our 2016 strategy on Slide 12. Our strategic priorities remain centered on driving growth by pressing our competitive advantage and investing to capture significant opportunities, such as the cloud-enabled enterprise. We will allocate capital towards these high-value opportunities and in turn will strengthen our economic model. 
In the near term, we will focus our energy on successfully integrating Telecity and Bit-isle and growing our market leadership globally. Organically, our efforts will be focused on capturing the enterprise through a series of initiatives to build cloud density, create and deploy innovative product solutions, generate demand in targeted segments and provide Professional Services focused on enabling the adoption of hybrid and multi-cloud. 
We will also continue to ramp our channel program to enhance our reach and to the enterprise through agents, resellers, systems integrators and key platform partners. Over the longer term, interconnection will continue to be the essence of our advantage, and Equinix is well positioned to become the intersection point between the Internet of Things, clouds, networks and the enterprises. 
We are making meaningful investments to foster new ecosystems to capture this opportunity, and we'll continue to invest in scaling our systems and processes and evolving our capabilities in response to these customer needs. 
Based on what we see in the market and the steps we are taking at Equinix to capitalize on these opportunities, I continue to be very optimistic about our future. And last on Slide 18, which summarizes our Q1 and full year 2016 guidance, including FX impacts. Let me cover a few thoughts on our 2016 outlook. 
First, we continue to deliver another solid year of growth. For the full year of 2016, we expect revenues to be greater than $3.55 billion, a 30% growth on an as-reported basis or a normalized and constant currency growth rate of greater than 13% year-over-year. 
Second, our organic adjusted EBITDA margin continues to improve as we drive increased efficiency into the business and scale our operating model. For 2016, adjusted EBITDA is expected to be greater than $1.62 billion or 16% year-over-year growth on a normalized and constant currency basis. This includes a 100 basis point adjusted EBITDA margin improvement for the Equinix organic business. 
And the growth of our business is driving increased adjusted funds from operations and ultimately cash flow and dividends. AFFO normalized for the Telecity transaction-related FX loss is expected to be greater than $1.078 billion, a 23% growth year-over-year, demonstrating the health of the business model. 
And finally, given our strong pipeline, firm yield and healthy returns, we continue to invest in our business and expect 2016 capital expenditures to range between $900 million and $1 billion for the year. 
So in closing, the strength of our business is translating into solid revenue growth, firm yield and healthy margins, all of which combine to give us the financial firepower to continue to invest in our global platform and develop innovative solutions. Our fundamental growth continues to drive significant value creation for our shareholders, a reflection of the important role that we play in the rapidly evolving digital economy. 
So let me stop here, and I'll turn it over to you, Sam, to open it up for questions.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Jonathan Schildkraut with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Jonathan Schildkraut with Evercore ISI.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Steve, if I could, I'd love to review a couple of the sort of big-ticket items that you guys brought to the conversation last quarter and see if we can get an update on them. And I guess the 3 things that really stand out are last quarter, you ta
componenttext: I guess, Steve, if I could, I'd love to review a couple of the sort of big-ticket items that you guys brought to the conversation last quarter and see if we can get an update on them. And I guess the 3 things that really stand out are last quarter, you talked about a second consecutive quarter of positive pricing actions. You talked about an accelerating TAM and you talked about the beginning of the emergence of cloud-driven enterprise demand. And while you highlighted enterprise amongst the verticals that were strong, I'd certainly love to hear anything explicit as it applies to sort of again cloud-driven enterprise demand. So just if you could sort of review us on those 3 points.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Why don't I start with a couple of comments and Charles and Keith can chime in here. Those are 3 good questions, Jonathan. The pricing actions continue to be favorable to us as we renew and move forward with existing customers that are extending in
componenttext: Sure. Why don't I start with a couple of comments and Charles and Keith can chime in here. Those are 3 good questions, Jonathan. The pricing actions continue to be favorable to us as we renew and move forward with existing customers that are extending in multiple markets with us. So we're staying very disciplined with our activities and our actions and our deal reviews with our customers as they continue to grow into the global platform. And so that's showing up every quarter. And I would just tell you that's tied to the discipline of our deal reviews and how we manage that and Charles can talk about that in a second because he sits on top of those. The accelerating TAM generally is because we're prosecuting a dozen-plus other industry verticals that we refer to as the enterprise outside of our core 5 industry verticals that we've been focused on, and it goes to these hundreds of thousands of customers, prospects, I should say, that we're knocking on our doorknob via the channel or via the direct sales engine to talk to them about helping them enable them to get to the multi-cloud and get to the hybrid cloud environment. So the cloud enterprise, the simple answer, the reason why we're a cloud enabling these data centers is to replicate the network density that we achieved the first 16, 17 years of this company to make it easy for any CIO of an enterprise to look inside these facilities and see that they can publicly, privately move their traffic, certain applications that are mission-critical, revenue-facing, customer-focused applications that they can get them to the multi-cloud and get them to take advantage of the performance to cost and the IT transformation that's taking place. So it's -- we're seeing uplift across all 3 of these things because of generally because of the uptake in cloud and cloud is driving most of this. Charles, why don't you add a little bit of color here?

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, all 3 of these things continue. The continued positive pricing actions, and as Steve said, that's showing up in our yield, continuing to be very firm across the board in terms of MRR per cab. The accelerating TAM is really absolutely linked to
componenttext: Yes. Again, all 3 of these things continue. The continued positive pricing actions, and as Steve said, that's showing up in our yield, continuing to be very firm across the board in terms of MRR per cab. The accelerating TAM is really absolutely linked to this enterprise phenomenon and building and the scaling of the cloud ecosystem, both the cloud density CSP side of that ecosystem as well as the enterprise. And I think we've had -- continue to have a number of big lighthouse wins. And what I would tell you is that I think this is probably the eighth consecutive quarter that both cloud and enterprise has overindexed on a bookings basis relative to their installed base, meaning that those who were continuing to see an evolution of the business not because our mature ecosystems are waning but rather because we're seeing an acceleration in the cloud ecosystem. And this big addressable market is really an artifact of people migrating to the cloud, adopting public cloud, using Equinix as a private access option to the public cloud and really enabling -- really selecting multi-cloud hybrid cloud as the IT architecture of choice. And I think if you look at it -- if you look at our core metrics, the business really hitting on all cylinders against all 3 of those factors.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Can you maybe just talk a little bit about the external growth opportunity that you're seeing? Obviously, there's a lot of chatter about the telco data center divestitures out there. And how you see your appetite for acquisitions and whether you would consider different structures such as JVs and the like if the opportunity arises and kind of how you might see that play out in 2016?

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Steve. Why don't I take that and let Keith and Charles add to what here. So most or all of you should be aware that publicly, there are a couple of big telcos that are interested in trying to divest some assets. And these are both the big te
componenttext: Paul, this is Steve. Why don't I take that and let Keith and Charles add to what here. So most or all of you should be aware that publicly, there are a couple of big telcos that are interested in trying to divest some assets. And these are both the big telcos that acquired cloud companies 3, 4, 5 years ago. And it includes those cloud data centers. It's public. It's -- their position talking to several people. We are one of them. And it -- our position is there are certain assets in those portfolios that we would be interested in. Obviously, where there's cloud network density and the power and location but there's many of those assets that wouldn't make any sense for us. So we're in the early stages, exploratory stages, talking to these companies. Those are the 2 that are public. There's other conversations going on. There's plenty of companies interested in getting out of the data center business. So it's a very active market on top of the divestiture that Keith mentioned that we're doing in Europe. So there's a lot of activity, mostly pressure-driven by the big Infrastructure-as-a-Service companies who are going as fast as they are, AWS, Microsoft, Google, et cetera, and they're putting a lot of pressure on companies in the decided to get into the Infrastructure-as-a-Service business and now they're deciding to get out of it. And the data centers are going with it. The telcos probably aimed at most of that cash that we collect on these will be aimed at, as you all know, in spectrum and aimed at their mobile initiatives. And so it makes sense why we're looking at these. But I said, there are specific assets that would make sense to us, but it's very early days in the dialogue. Charles, I don't know [indiscernible].

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I think you covered most of it. The only 1 point you talked about in there, Paul, that might be worth touching on is whether we would consider JVs or other creative commercial structures. I would say that I think to the extent that there were str
componenttext: I guess, I think you covered most of it. The only 1 point you talked about in there, Paul, that might be worth touching on is whether we would consider JVs or other creative commercial structures. I would say that I think to the extent that there were structures that would allow us to potentially gain access to the assets that we see as most accretive to our strategy and on point from a capital allocation standpoint for us, we would entertain those. But there -- I think there are only a very select set of assets that really support our interconnection-rich ecosystem-based strategy. And so we would be focused on those most likely. And I think to the extent we could be other creative ways to get that to happen, we would consider those. But we also have a lot to right now in terms of getting the integrations done and so remain very focused on executing the business.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'll add to all these, Steve, just one last comment, is we'll remain proactive but highly selective in any potential M&A for this type of discussion. And as Charles said, it would have to pass through the filters of -- it would extend our g
componenttext: The only thing I'll add to all these, Steve, just one last comment, is we'll remain proactive but highly selective in any potential M&A for this type of discussion. And as Charles said, it would have to pass through the filters of -- it would extend our global platform. It would help enhance our interconnection or our network density. It would help us capture the cloud enterprise discussion that we're having. If it passes those filters, we're going to take a close look at it.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I mean, in Telecity's case, obviously, there's some noncore assets that you're planning to divest. But I guess in this case, would it be fair to say that just because of the scale of what you would classify as noncore that taking on major portfolio
componenttext: Great. I mean, in Telecity's case, obviously, there's some noncore assets that you're planning to divest. But I guess in this case, would it be fair to say that just because of the scale of what you would classify as noncore that taking on major portfolios where a majority or a big chunk of the assets are  have to be pegged for sale is not kind of what you're looking for?

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, what I'd like to first say is unfortunately, the assets that we're selling are not -- they're not noncore. They're effectively mandated through our work with the European regulatory authority. Clearly to us, we would love to keep all of the assets i
componenttext: Paul, what I'd like to first say is unfortunately, the assets that we're selling are not -- they're not noncore. They're effectively mandated through our work with the European regulatory authority. Clearly to us, we would love to keep all of the assets in our portfolio. With that all said, it goes back to what Charles and Steve alluded to. They said that we can acquire assets that are accretive to our overall strategy and create value for our shareholders, those acquisitions or joint ventures. We absolutely will pursue them. But we are very much focused on, as Steve alluded to, driving investment decisions that support our cloud-enabled strategy, extend our global reach and enhance our interconnection activities.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Rollins with Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Rollins with Citi Investment Research.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give us a bit more of a look into the integration process for the 2 acquisitions that you completed? And what are the major milestones that investors should be watching over?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us a bit more of a look into the integration process for the 2 acquisitions that you completed? And what are the major milestones that investors should be watching over?

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Michael, Charles and I will take this one. Let me first start with Bit-isle because I think that's an important one, then Charles perhaps you can take the Telecity one. I think what's really important to understand about Bit-isle, as we said in ou
componenttext: I think Michael, Charles and I will take this one. Let me first start with Bit-isle because I think that's an important one, then Charles perhaps you can take the Telecity one. I think what's really important to understand about Bit-isle, as we said in our prepared remarks, revenues are essentially flat quarter-over-quarter. And I want sort of investors to realize, from a margin perspective, Bit-isle is dilutive to our margins today. It is very clear to us given the inventory capacity they have in the Tokyo market specifically. This was an asset that we bought for a sub-10x multiple to EBITDA. We believe upon filling up our assets we're going to be able to enjoy the ability to fill up their assets over a period of time, while at the same time assessing, if you will, the strategic landscape of the number of operating units that Bit-isle had. And so as a company, we fully intend, over a reasonable period of time, it will not be over an 18- or 24-month period but probably over the next 3 to 4 years, that we would be able to capture all of the value associated with the Bit-isle acquisition, fill up their assets and get their margins up to basically where our Asia Pacific business is running today, which is in the 45% to 50% EBITDA margin basis. But we're being very disciplined about this acquisition. Culturally, it's a meaningful acquisition for us, and we're very sensitive to the environment that we are operating in. But we recognize in the investment decision that over the short term, we weren't going to see any meaningful uplift in the business model. And accretive from day 1 because we use debt to buy the asset. We're going to be very methodical about how we drive valley into that acquisition. Charles, you want to...

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of process, Mike, I guess I'd make a couple of comments. I think these are obviously both somewhat localized assets with Telecity being a strictly European platform and Bit-isle really being contained to Japan. So our local teams both in the
componenttext: Yes, in terms of process, Mike, I guess I'd make a couple of comments. I think these are obviously both somewhat localized assets with Telecity being a strictly European platform and Bit-isle really being contained to Japan. So our local teams both in the EMEA region and in Japan have the primary responsibility for driving the integration efforts. That said, we did take in individual from my team who is really in my right hand for quite a while when I ran the Americas business and into my role as the COO, who really understands our business deeply, has a deep network across the company. We've actually exported him to -- and he's living in Amsterdam now with his family and is leading the integration effort for Telecity and sort of providing overall oversight to our integration activities in terms of aligning them, keeping them consistent in approach, identifying and applying best practices, et cetera. So that's kind of how we're going about it. In terms of the metrics I think to watch, we're obviously watching them very closely, and we will update you as appropriate on these. But I think they are, number one, what -- how are we doing on integrating the sales teams and driving the upsell and the cross-sell activities? And that's one we're probably not going to give a ton of granular insight into publicly, but it's something that we obviously are watching very, very closely and feel very optimistic about. Secondly, the synergy capture. We talked about what we expect in terms of synergies, and we're driving the teams to those expectations to meet or exceed our synergy estimates from an energy standpoint. And then we're aligning our capital planning processes to make sure that we're gaining the capital -- the CapEx energies where we can and ensuring that we continue to have the capacity to respond to the fill rates in high demand markets. And then lastly, I think probably keeping an eye on our progress on the divestiture, and again, we'll report our progress to you on that as we have it.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from David Barden with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question is from David Barden with Bank of America.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I have to ask the kind of banal financial question, which is, I guess Keith, I think the market expectation was for AFFO number becoming probably $50 million or $60 million north of the $1.078 billion you kind of called out here. I feel like that
componenttext: I guess, I have to ask the kind of banal financial question, which is, I guess Keith, I think the market expectation was for AFFO number becoming probably $50 million or $60 million north of the $1.078 billion you kind of called out here. I feel like that probably had a lot to do with people not expecting a lot of the assets just to be moved into discontinued ops right away. Could you put in a AFFO number alongside the $77 million EBITDA number that you pulled out of the guidance for those divested assets, so we could kind of look at a pro forma more normalized number? And then the other moving parts on that would be great. And then second, again along the same lines, just to make sure, so we're all on the same page, in terms of the share count we want to be you seeing now, so we're looking at an AFFO per share, I think that there's a lot of numbers on Slide 38 in terms of the share count. And I if you can kind of tell us -- or 35, which one of these is the one we're supposed to be using to look at valuation?

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Certainly, David. I think first and foremost, I think Page 35 clearly depicts the share count activity that you should be expecting, both as we sit here at the end of 12/31/15 and then certainly what you should expect on a go-forward basis. And so t
componenttext: Okay. Certainly, David. I think first and foremost, I think Page 35 clearly depicts the share count activity that you should be expecting, both as we sit here at the end of 12/31/15 and then certainly what you should expect on a go-forward basis. And so the numbers that I shared with you, the roughly 6.9 million [ph] shares will be issued to the Telecity shareholders and then the 1.96 million shares issued to convertible debt owners. That all said, I think there is somewhat -- there appears to be some clarity over what the base denominator share count. And so will discussion has to go into what's sitting up in the numerator. I think the most important thing is, as you've sort of alluded to, David, there is -- the divestiture is certainly, it's a meaningful divestiture. There's 8 assets as you can see. As reflected in our bridge, you can see there's roughly $70 million of revenue that's being taken -- sorry, pardon me, $70 million of EBITDA that's been taken out of the analysis and that's on Slide 14 for those who are following along. A lot of that value recognizing, that's coming right out of the AFFO base. There's nothing that [indiscernible] drag, along with that recognizing, of course, there'll be some movement in maybe how we recognize the revenue or the deferred installation. But overall, that's almost a complete drop-through to the AFFO line. And as a result, when we step back and look at how is the business performing relative to expectations, I think it's really important to note 2 things. Number one, is Equinix proper is driving more margin into the business? Not only did we do it this year, but we're setting ourselves up to do next year being 2016. So that $100 million -- the 100 basis points of improvement is certainly being realized. You can see that Telecity is coming in on -- with the assets, they're going to have a margin profile that's higher than Equinix proper. And then we're also going to continue to work on synergies in the business. So that's going to continue to add value to the go forward valuation. And then as I said earlier on, Bit-isle is the one piece we recognize that is relatively flat over a period of time. But we recognize that as we continue to synergize the business, as Charles alluded to, and drive up the occupancy of their asset, that's going to drive more value into the top line. So I think the combination of those 3 assets, the organic the 2 acquisitions and knowing that we are growing faster than certainly than we anticipated in 2015, and we think we've got a great growth rate coming into '16 at this stage of the game at greater than 13% organically, we're optimistic that the numerator will be -- will drive a lot of value into the per share calculations. All of that to say is we got to get through 2016. 2016's no different than 2015 when we convert to a REIT. 2016, there's a lot of noise in the system, not only with the REIT conversion and all the other work that we still are doing but also taking the Telecity assets and moving them into the structure. And so the costs to do that are substantial, but the benefits that we will realize from the Telecity acquisition, Steve's talked about there's revenues, there's cost, there's CapEx but there's also much more efficient tax structure that we will operate in under our structure, if you will. And all of that benefit you're really going to feel it more in '17 than you are in '16. And so you've going to look through '16 to recognize '17, I think sets us up well. The currency issues should be gone. The integration costs will really -- we expect them to have really been dialed out and the operating business should be accelerating as we've alluded to.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jonathan Atkin with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jonathan Atkin with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick ones. I wondered if you could talk a little bit about the churn expectations. You gave it on a company-wide basis and if there's any regional variations to keep in mind. And then on the interconnects, I just wondered if you could discuss
componenttext: A couple of quick ones. I wondered if you could talk a little bit about the churn expectations. You gave it on a company-wide basis and if there's any regional variations to keep in mind. And then on the interconnects, I just wondered if you could discuss in a little bit more detail the growth in interconnection, how much of that is coming from Cloud Exchange versus conventional cross connects. And then Steve, in response to Jonathan's question, you alluded to the indirect channel and [indiscernible] Charles can maybe comment on the portion of new bookings that you had described your indirect, which is relatively [indiscernible] of yours.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Why don't you start with churn, Keith? And then I'll pass it on to Charles and Steve. I think one thing about churn, let me break it down maybe not in -- let me break it down between the organic business Equinix proper. I would tell you our churn levels a
componenttext: Why don't you start with churn, Keith? And then I'll pass it on to Charles and Steve. I think one thing about churn, let me break it down maybe not in -- let me break it down between the organic business Equinix proper. I would tell you our churn levels are at or near their best in a long, long time. That holds true also for 2016. As I mentioned, churn in Q4 was 2.3%. We telegraphed them being slightly higher. It was attributed to a single customer in our U.K. business that we knew that we'd be relocating to their own specialty build data center. That said, as we look forward, we see churn to be again at one of its lowest levels, I think, we ever experienced as a company organically. As you then go into the 2 other assets, the Telecity assets and the Bit-isle asset, Telecity is going to be really no different than what you see at the Equinix level. We're going to see slightly increased churn is really in Bit-isle. And a lot of reasons for when you look at how Bit-isle did in 2014 relative to 2015 and what we're guiding to 2016, there's a number of factors. Number one, they've got nonrecurring activities that will not repeat themselves. They have a little bit  to have an operating units and have built solar plant and sold off some of those assets. That was sitting in their '14 results, it's not in '15. Equally so, they have suffered some substantial churn. They've done exactly what we chose not to do, which is effectively build up a large portion of their inventory with some large customers. And when those customers run into trouble, as you can appreciate, vendors are fairly meaningful churn event. That's what Bit-isle is suffering through not only in '15, and that's why their value was so low, but also, we're still going to feel some of that in '16. And so from my perspective, churn will be, I think, at a very strong level looking into '16.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I'll hit the other point. But to point out the churn and just say that again what we continue to see is just the discipline in the business and this commitment to the right application in the right asset, right customers, right applications, righ
componenttext: Yes, and I'll hit the other point. But to point out the churn and just say that again what we continue to see is just the discipline in the business and this commitment to the right application in the right asset, right customers, right applications, right asset continues to manifest itself both in terms of the positive price actions and correspondingly to the moderated churn levels. So I think it's absolutely a reflection of the strategy working as we would expect. The other 2 topics were interconnection. I would say that interconnection obviously, an incredibly strong quarter with 7,500 cross connects in aggregate. We track that at a very detailed level vertical essentially done on the firm [indiscernible] by every vertical. And every cell in the matrix is growing. The fastest-growing are the cloud-related sort of the cloud ecosystem on a percentage basis. But the most, in terms, the biggest contributor continues to be our mature network ecosystem. And the financial services ecosystem continues to contribute significantly. So -- but on a percentage basis, cloud is overindexing dramatically like 5x probably its installed base. And that's just a reflection of, I think, the early days of that and really starting to sort of take shape and scale as enterprises are adopting hybrid cloud. I would also say that part of the driver in the network adds on cross connects is these 300 customers that have adopted Performance Hub, many of whom are using that for WAN optimization strategies and therefore, driving significant cross connects to network providers. So that's a snapshot on interconnection. And then lastly on channel. What I would tell you is that we, over the last couple of quarters, have seen a number of our lighthouse marquee deals in the enterprise come through partners. And I think that's a reflection of many of those customers are finding that they need some combination of the infrastructure value delivered by Platform Equinix but desire a managed service element of that implementation. And our partners are doing that very effectively. And so we won some very big deals as we referenced in the script from -- through partners with our enterprise lighthouse wins. And we are seeing, in terms of allocation of percentage of bookings coming through indirect continue to grow steadily. And we're really focusing on set a high-impact partners that we think will help us continue to drive that through '16.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've talked a lot about the various regions and you really haven't bought up macro at all. We look at the market performance, we look at the headlines, and it really doesn't seem like it's pretty tough out there, particularly in some of the internationa
componenttext: You've talked a lot about the various regions and you really haven't bought up macro at all. We look at the market performance, we look at the headlines, and it really doesn't seem like it's pretty tough out there, particularly in some of the international markets. So are you seeing anything from your customers? Or are the secular trends still very healthy at this point? And perhaps you could just give us a little bit more color on the sale process. I think you had said midyear. What gives you confidence that it'll be wrapped up by then? And are you likely to do one transaction or might this be multiple transactions?

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve, I'll start out and we'll triple team it here. In terms of the market -- macro trends, I know -- I think we all followed IDC or Gartner [indiscernible] that the IT spend globally was slowing down at the end of last year. And I think this goe
componenttext: This is Steve, I'll start out and we'll triple team it here. In terms of the market -- macro trends, I know -- I think we all followed IDC or Gartner [indiscernible] that the IT spend globally was slowing down at the end of last year. And I think this goes back to what Charles said. Because we're so focused on the type of application workload with our client base that is not considered discretionary and it's more mission-critical, even in volatile times, as Keith alluded to, we tend to perform better than the market because we're dealing with revenue customer-facing globally deployed type application workloads that are critical around these businesses. So because of our discipline on executing in that part of the application workload of our customer base and that part of the -- that's non-back office, non-server farm type workload, we tend to push right through this. And the demand that we see from our customer base today is high, trying to figure out how to take advantage of the cloud computing model. And so our pipeline, if you were able to see in our pipeline, which you guys can't, you would see very good coverage ratios, and you would see the strongest pipeline in the history of the company. So the signals for us across all the regions or M&A themselves in our pipeline and M&A in our coverage ratios. And all I can tell you at this point is they are strong as they've ever been. And Charles, I don't know what you would add to that.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, just countering the macro IT spending environment, which is -- I mean, that environment is being impacted heavily by public cloud adoption and adoption of hybrid cloud, multi-cloud as the architecture of choice. And so if you really look at
componenttext: Yes, I guess, just countering the macro IT spending environment, which is -- I mean, that environment is being impacted heavily by public cloud adoption and adoption of hybrid cloud, multi-cloud as the architecture of choice. And so if you really look at the portion that we tend to play and around -- if you look at the growth of AWS, look at Microsoft's Azure revenues and their cloud participation, look at what Oracle is doing in terms of retooling their business into the cloud, those are all significant customers of ours. They're all scaling globally with us. And then we are really leveraging that cloud density with that sort of core group as well as very long tail of SaaS to really attract the enterprise customer and seeing some momentum there. So -- it is an environment, although there's market volatility and pressure I think on CIOs to manage spending and reduce expense, et cetera, they're often coming to us as a way to achieve those means. And whether that's reducing network costs, adopting public cloud at an accelerated rate or implementing hybrid cloud and moving out of their basement and avoiding spending that capital, those are all things that they can really use us for, so we feel well positioned even though there's some choppiness in the overall macro environment.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Including your final question, Simon, was really about the timing of the asset divestiture in Europe. Clearly, there's an expectation as we worked alongside the EU regulators and Telecity that we'd sell the assets over a certain period of time. That time
componenttext: Including your final question, Simon, was really about the timing of the asset divestiture in Europe. Clearly, there's an expectation as we worked alongside the EU regulators and Telecity that we'd sell the assets over a certain period of time. That time frame, which would be in or around midyear 2016, as Steve alluded to, we're well in the process -- well down in the process, if you will, at selling the assets. We have a number of interested buyers. And I think you just have to stay tuned, but we're very active and deep in the process right now, and we're confident that we will conclude it before near mid time this year or midyear.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mike McCormack with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mike McCormack with Jefferies.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, maybe just a follow-up on the undersea piece. Sounds like you guys are pretty excited about it. With respect to the sort of the types of traffic government regulation, are you guys set up better to address that marketplace based upon the geographic
componenttext: Steve, maybe just a follow-up on the undersea piece. Sounds like you guys are pretty excited about it. With respect to the sort of the types of traffic government regulation, are you guys set up better to address that marketplace based upon the geographic locations of your data centers? And then just secondly, maybe one for Keith. You identified some cost savings that are organic. Just let me get a sense for detail on when where you're finding that.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me take the first piece, Mike. There are a lot of new projects mostly driven by the requirements for -- to help support all this cloud -- global cloud deployment that's going on around and the growth of international traffic. So there really has
componenttext: Sure. Let me take the first piece, Mike. There are a lot of new projects mostly driven by the requirements for -- to help support all this cloud -- global cloud deployment that's going on around and the growth of international traffic. So there really hasn't been any new trans-Atlantic capacity been added in the last probably dozen years. And so there's -- until one of the announcements that came late last year or middle of last year, Express, which went live at Equinix so there's a lot of focus out there, some private investment partially funded by some of the big global -- the global cloud providers. It's definitely being driven by cloud. We're involved in many more conversations than we ever have in the future or in the past, I should say. And the investments in technology today is allowing these operators to bypass the traditional shore-based lending facilities and go all the way to terminating at a data center like Equinix so we're catching that volume now. There's been 4 or 5 public announcements that we've made of ones there that we participated in. There's been a couple of connected U.S. Japan, New York, London, and so there's a whole bunch going on now. We're probably involved in a dozen more projects today that are at different stages of assessment, development and construction so it is very active it is driven by the cloud and by the bandwidth amount of traffic around the world, and they can terminate these cables today very easily into data centers. And so we're front and center on this topic.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as it relates to basically the question on cost savings. I think what's most important to note, Mike, is we're not going in and cutting costs. What we're doing today is we're operating more efficiently. And it's important to recognize over the la
componenttext: And then as it relates to basically the question on cost savings. I think what's most important to note, Mike, is we're not going in and cutting costs. What we're doing today is we're operating more efficiently. And it's important to recognize over the last 3 to 4 years, we've made heavy investments across a number of different functional groups to scale the organization to be global. And one of the biggest investments we've made has been in our IT systems and platforms and the people that's really continue to work very hard to make them run as efficiently as possible. And then we build processes and structures around them. That said, we've made those initial investments. We're investing in sale and sort of and customer-facing initiatives, which I would argue is driving a lot of the value that we see today. But we're also finding ways to reallocate our cost. And part of our efforts today not only as it related to '15 but also as we look to '16 is how do we run more efficiently and take resources that we're spending money in and run them more efficiently, so we can put it back into the business differently. And in fact, there's roughly $24 million of cost that we reallocated in our organization to support our investments in 2016. And so we feel very comfortable about that but quite frankly, it's a work in progress. We have to continue to lever off our systems, our processes, our people. And that's something that you will see in '16 but you're also going to see us globalize bring in Telecity we bring in Bit-isle over the next -- through '17, '18 and '19 will continue to make this investments and I would argue that can drive more value into the business.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question is from Colby Synesael of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And our last question is from Colby Synesael of Cowen and Company.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, at the risk of up materially I'm going to ask 3 questions. But they're all modeling so hopefully, you can [indiscernible] pretty quickly. The first one is on Telecity. I was curious what tax rate we should thinking about for 2016. My understandin
componenttext: I guess, at the risk of up materially I'm going to ask 3 questions. But they're all modeling so hopefully, you can [indiscernible] pretty quickly. The first one is on Telecity. I was curious what tax rate we should thinking about for 2016. My understanding is there's U.K. tax jurisdiction, which is different than how you guys treat your European assets. And when is it that we might actually see Telecity shift from its current tax structure to that of the overall Equinix business? The second one is on 2017. You mentioned that you thought that Telecity would be accretive to 2017 after integration costs. You mentioned, integration costs, I think, in 2017 will be $20 million. Will be accretive even including those integration costs? And then the third question is on Telecity and your FX hedge. I think a mentioned that you hedge about 80% of your core business in Europe. Do you plan on hedging any of the Telecity revenues at some point this year and perhaps how much would those be?

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great questions, Colby. I think first and foremost, as it relates to the tax rates, probably a little bit premature for us to tell you what that's going to be because part of the reason we're making such a substantial investment in integration costs
componenttext: Okay, great questions, Colby. I think first and foremost, as it relates to the tax rates, probably a little bit premature for us to tell you what that's going to be because part of the reason we're making such a substantial investment in integration costs in 2016 is to change in the organizational structure to meet not only our REIT requirements but our commissioner requirements. And so suffice it to say, we feel that overall, our global tax rate will continue to be in the 10% to 15% cash rate basis. We, as a company and certainly our European business pretty organically has a lower tax rate than that of our competitors, and so we think we can benefit from that. So stay tuned on that one. Let us come back but there's a lot of work to deal with there. As it relates to Telecity on the FX side, I think it's important to note we have hedged 85% of the organic business. We have yet to take the position on the Telecity business in Europe primarily because their functional currency is not U.S. dollar. Our functional currency in Europe is U.S. dollar. And so the hedging strategies we would deploy aren't going to be different today at least for Equinix proper versus the Telecity asset. But suffice it to say, we're going to be looking very closely and try not to destroy value of the currency movement. So again, stay tuned on that one. And I'm sorry, I have the third one was...

componenttextpreview: Pardon me, the 2017. Yes, the combined business, including integration is going to be accretive in 2017 relative if I'm not doing these transactions, so we are very -- and again, we want you to look through '16 to '17 with those $20 million of cost we wil
componenttext: Pardon me, the 2017. Yes, the combined business, including integration is going to be accretive in 2017 relative if I'm not doing these transactions, so we are very -- and again, we want you to look through '16 to '17 with those $20 million of cost we will be accretive in '17, if you will, on a combined basis with our asset. But the one thing I certainly want to make -- leave you with this you have to recognize, by the time we start to go through the year and integrate these assets as Charles alluded to, the assets are going to become fungible. And so whether we sell into a Telecity asset or at Bit-isle asset or in Equinix organic asset and how we move our [indiscernible] that's we've got to look at holistically in '17 recognize there's going to be a lot of moving parts. There's going to be synergies, there's going to be integration costs. So holistically, I want you to walk away, 2017 is an accretive year for us, and we're very excited to work through this year over the next 10 months to get to where we need to be.
