headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Equinix Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If anyone has objections, please disconnect at this time. I'd now like to turn the call over to Katrina
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Equinix Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If anyone has objections, please disconnect at this time. I'd now like to turn the call over to Katrina Rymill, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to today's conference call. Before we get started, I'd like to remind everyone that some of the statements we'll be making today are forward-looking in nature and involve risks and uncertainties. Actual results may v
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to today's conference call. Before we get started, I'd like to remind everyone that some of the statements we'll be making today are forward-looking in nature and involve risks and uncertainties. Actual results may vary significantly from those statements and may be affected by the risks we identified in today's press release and those identified in our filings with the SEC, including our most recent Form 10-K filed on February 26, 2016, and 10-Q filed on May 9, 2016. Equinix assumes no obligation and does not intend to update or comment on forward-looking statements made on this call.
In addition, in light of Regulation Fair Disclosure, it is Equinix' policy not to comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it is done through an explicit public disclosure. In addition, we'll provide non-GAAP measures on today's conference call. We provide a reconciliation of those measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures and a list of the reasons why the company uses these measures in today's press release on the Equinix Investor Relations page at www.equinix.com.
We would also like to remind you that we post important information about Equinix on the Investor Relations page of our website. We encourage you to check our website regularly for the most current available information. 
With us today are Steve Smith, Equinix' CEO and President; Keith Taylor, Chief Financial Officer; and Charles Meyers, Chief Operating Officer. Following our prepared remarks, we'll be taking questions from sell-side analysts. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'll turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Katrina, and good afternoon, and welcome to our second quarter earnings call. We had a great first half of 2016, delivering both revenues and adjusted EBITDA above the top end of our guidance range as our global scale and reach, strength of
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Katrina, and good afternoon, and welcome to our second quarter earnings call. We had a great first half of 2016, delivering both revenues and adjusted EBITDA above the top end of our guidance range as our global scale and reach, strength of our digital ecosystems and service excellence continue to drive profitable growth. 
As depicted on Slide 3 of our presentation, second quarter revenues were $900.5 million, up 3% quarter-over-quarter and up 15% over the same quarter last year on an organic and constant-currency basis. Adjusted EBITDA was $420.3 million for the quarter, up 5% over the prior quarter and up 18% year-over-year on an organic and constant-currency basis. This drove AFFO growth of 37% year-over-year on a normalized and constant-currency basis. 
We delivered strong growth in net bookings, with increasing contribution from our indirect channel. Our key operating metrics continue to be very healthy with firm MRR per cabinet, low churn and strong growth in both billable cabinet and interconnection. We continue to progress against key operational and business objectives in 2016 to grow our market position globally, generating on successful acquisition integration, sustained organic development and scaling our interconnection services. So let me provide some commentary in each of these in turn. 
Starting with acquisition. We are focusing our energy on successfully integrating Telecity and Bit-isle, scaling the business to drive even more value for our customers and enhancing our cloud and network density across EMEA and Asia. We've delivered against key integration goals and milestones and are pleased with the progress we have made in the first half. 
The Telecity business delivered solid financial performance despite normal integration challenges and complexity associated with the divestitures, and we are seeing value creation across a broad range of synergy categories. Our EMEA sales force has been fully integrated, and our cost selling program is tracking ahead of plan, with particular customer interest in the overlapping markets of London and Amsterdam and our new markets in Stockholm and Manchester. 
The financial and IT systems work is well underway, and we've defined the critical initiatives to operationally integrate our back op [ph] We have completed the first large systems conversion with the Telecity Dutch business now operating within the Equinix corporate systems and processes and plan to migrate the remaining countries through 2017. 
In early July, we also completed the sale of 8 European assets for $882 million, updated for FX as we required by the European  Commission as part of its approval of our purchase of Telecity Group. Completing this last milestone in the acquisition process paves the way for us to fully focus on selling our newly combined European platform. 
We're also pleased with Bit-isle's progress and the market reaction to the acquisition has been positive. The business is performing well, with cross-selling momentum accelerating including several wins with Japanese multinationals that are leveraging space and connectivity across existing and acquired sites. We are further optimizing this business by divesting 2 small noncore businesses, which we completed in the first half of 2016. We also expect to divest Terra Power, a collection of solar power assets in the second half of this year. 
Turning to our organic development activity. We continue to invest in expanding globally, allocating 95% of our expansion capital to building off-campus our existing market build or a deep knowledge of fill rate, pipeline and competitive supply to higher returns. We now have 19 announced expansion projects underway, and in this quarter, we are moving forward with additional expansions in Ashburn, Frankfurt, Paris and Singapore totaling over $250 million of capital expenditures. 
We are starting work on DC12, the first data center build in our Ashburn, in Northern Virginia, which is on 44 acres of owned, undeveloped land next to our current Ashburn North Campus. Today, Ashburn is one of our major campuses with over 14,000 cabinets across 10 IBX, and it's the largest Internet exchange point in North America. The new Ashburn North Campus, which we plan to develop over the next few years, will expand our asset ownership and effectively double our capacity in this important market. 
Turning to Frankfurt, we see continued demand in this vibrant market coming from Internet and cloud providers due to data sovereignty compliance as well as financial services growth. We are building Frankfurt 6, a new IBX located on owned land next to Frankfurt 4 and tethered to our core network hub in this market. 
These capital investments are delivering very healthy growth and strong returns as shown on Slide 4. Revenues from our 70 stabilized IBXs grew 8% year-over-year, above our historical trend line and largely driven by an increase in cross connect and power density. We continue to find ways to optimize our asset base, putting the right customer and application into the right assets, which drives a firm yield per cabinet. These stabilized assets are generating a 32% cash on cash return on the gross PP&E invested and utilization remains at a stable 86%. 
In terms of our asset ownership strategy, our goal is to produce over 50% from owned properties over time by developing land such as in Silicon Valley and Ashburn as well as purchasing additional site as it makes economic and strategic sense. Consistent with this strategy, we purchased our Paris 2 and 3 IBXs for $211 million from Digital Realty, which closed this week. 
Over 70 carriers reside in Paris 2 and 3 most densely connected data center campus in France. Ownership will enable us to achieve better operating costs, enhanced customer service and further expand this campus over time. The acquisition of Paris 2 and 3 is an example of where we can acquire assets and operate the property more efficiently for our own purpose, thereby allowing us to enjoy a higher return. With this purchase, 35% of our revenues now come from owned assets. 
Turning to interconnection. The need to build next-generation IT architectures that connect network, cloud, people and data continues to drive customer demand for interconnection. We now have 183,000 cross connects, and interconnection revenue grew 21% year-over-year on an organic and constant-currency basis. 
Interconnection revenues represent 16% of our global recurring revenues, and this is the eighth quarter in a row where we had a greater than 5,000 cross connects. We saw particularly strong growth in connections to cloud providers, with accelerated additions of participants and virtual circuit on our market-leading Cloud Exchange platform and strong sales of cross connect to facilitate direct connect into pure play cloud. 
Our Internet exchange continues to scale with 5.6 terabits of peak traffic, growing over 35% year-over-year as network and cloud providers upgrade their capacity and transition to 100-gig equipment. The transition to cloud continues to unfold as enterprises are re-architecting IT to drive down costs, improve performance and leverage clouds and network. 
We continue to see growth in Fortune 500 new customer and expansion wins as the explosion of data and devices are transforming how large multinationals architect their infrastructure leveraging interconnection as a core design principle. We added 7 new Fortune 500 customers in the quarter such as Ticketmaster, an online ticket vendor, leveraging Equinix to improve digital experience and integrate cloud infrastructure. We now have over 150 of the Fortune 500 customers and over 500 of the Global 2000. 
Now let me cover quarterly highlights from our industry vertical, starting with the network. This vertical experienced strong bookings, led by strength in Asia as wireline providers including Telstra, SingTel and Softbank expanded with multi-region deployment. We saw growth with regional Internet service providers including U.S. Internet Corp., a regional ISP peering to support growing enterprise cloud demand; and GCI, a regional telecom provider, adding cloud connectivity capabilities via our Cloud Exchange to augment their network service offering. 
Additionally, our strength as a global platform allows us to target strategic subsea cable projects to land within our ecosystem hub. And we are seeing pipeline and activity build in this growing segment including 2 new wins this quarter. Equinix is the biggest aggregator of digital ecosystems, making us the most logical choice for subsea cable operators to get the immediate benefit tapping into a mature ecosystem of buyers. 
The financial services vertical experienced continued expansion into our core electronic trading ecosystem as well as diversification into other subsegments. This quarter, we saw additional expansions from investment banks such as Morgan Stanley better leveraging Equinix for critical data center, network and cloud connectivity. We are also observing the beginning of clustering of electronic payment counterparties across regions, including the addition of Merchant Customer Exchange, a leading merchant payment system that is deployed to peer traffic and connect to multiple clouds. 
In the content digital media vertical, advertisers from digital media were the growth drivers for booking. Asia delivered strong bookings this quarter, reflecting digital adoption in the region. Customer wins included Index Exchange, a premier ad tech firm leveraging Ad-IX and a content discovery platform, optimizing performance at the edge to better serve the APAC region. 
The cloud and IT service vertical is the second fastest-growing vertical, driven by cloud hyperscalars continue to deploy globally as well strategic wins with leading SaaS providers. Our traction in the Software as a Service base is enhancing the value of our platform to enterprise clients. We are also observing a maturity cycle where many SaaS providers launch in the public cloud then transition to hybrid cloud as they scale and service their wider customer base. We had a great quarter for cloud services adoption, with over 460 enterprises, clouds, IT service providers and networks now interconnecting on our Cloud Exchange. 
Turning to the enterprise. This vertical continues to be the fastest-growing vertical, with a record number of performance hub deployments this quarter. Wins included a Fortune 100 manufacturer that is re-architecting by building edge note at Equinix; and a U.S. federal agency providing delivery services that is deploying multiple performance hubs and integrating multiple clouds on our platform. 
Today, over 470 customers have deployed our performance hub solution, which helps enterprises optimize their network architectures, access the cloud and drive application performance. Updated for acquisition, cloud and IT services and enterprise verticals now represent 29% and 14% of our revenues, respectively, and we continue to expect these verticals to lead growth as we progress with enterprise cloud adoption. 
And finally, we are seeing solid progress in our channel and partner programs as a percentage of our bookings coming from channel has increased from high single-digits 3 years ago to over 15% today. Our channel strategy leverages a range of partner types, each playing a critical role in scaling our enterprise 
Platform partners help us leverage mind share and awareness with high-value target customers committed to hybrid cloud as the IT architecture of choice. Referral partners create leverage in our lead generation engine, and resellers magnify our sales effort and combine key value-added services with Equinix offers to deliver complete solutions that more directly address the integrated needs of enterprise customers. 
By coordinating our sales activity with key partners at the local level, we've been able to meaningfully expand our market reach and have seen our channel program as our most prolific source of new logos for the past several quarters. So let me stop here and turn it over to Keith to cover some of the results for the quarter.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon to everyone in the call. It's great to be able to update you on our second quarter performance, our 54th quarter of top line revenue growth. By almost any measure, this was another strong quarter for Equinix. Since f
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon to everyone in the call. It's great to be able to update you on our second quarter performance, our 54th quarter of top line revenue growth. By almost any measure, this was another strong quarter for Equinix. 
Since first half 2016, we delivered results better than our expectations and created value for our investors by scaling revenues while improving margins, resulting in meaningful flow-through to adjusted EBITDA and AFFO, with an absolute dollar terms as well as on a per-share basis. 
The organic business continues to perform well, and our acquisitions are delivering against our expectations. Also the number of cross-sell successes and of the depth of the sales pipeline continues to grow. Overall, we're delighted with the progress of our integration efforts related to both Bit-isle and Telecity. 
sale has have moved up the margin curve faster than expected despite our anticipated higher churn levels, and we've optimized the business more quickly than originally planned. As Steve noted, we now expect sales [indiscernible] outbid our business lines prior to the end of the year. This allows us to focus on the higher-value colocation and interconnection offerings, along with some services in support of the local Tokyo market. 
With regard to Telecity, now that the divestiture process is complete, the team is highly focused on integrating the former Telecity businesses into Equinix as quickly as possible. In the July, we fully integrated the Dutch business, which is now operating within our systems and processes. This will soon be followed by the U.K., Irish and Swedish businesses over the next few quarters. 
With regards to our key operating metrics, as highlighted by Steve yet worth mentioning again, our IRR per cabinet yield remains firm at just over $2,000 per cabinet, up $18 on a constant-currency basis over the prior quarter, with particular strenght in the Americas region. Also, we added 3,300 net billable cabinets for the quarter, effectively returning to our normalized level. And the MR churn was lower than expected. 
With respect to our interconnection offerings, net gross connect addition remains very positive, adding another 6,100 in the quarter. Also, the provision capacity and traffic growth on our Internet exchange has substantially outpace our competitor, partially reflected by the meaningful increase in the number of 100-gig ports provisioned on our exchanges. As we measure the health and success of our exchanges, we now will report provision capacity in addition to the total port [indiscernible] to highlight the momentum we're seeing in the interconnection offering. 
I would like to add a few on the foreign currency improvement in the quarter. The U.S. dollar weakened during the back half of Q1 through most of Q2 against many of our operating currency. This resulted in a meaningful FX benefit for the second quarter relative to Q1. 
However, following the Brexit announcement on June 24, the U.S. dollar strengthened significantly against the British pound and the euro. Despite these FX movements, we expect no significant change in either our 2016 revenue or adjusted EBITDA guidance related to FX movements as many of the other operating currencies that we operate in strengthened against the U.S. dollar in Q2.
Now we continue to place currency hedges into our business to produce financial volatility and protect currency of our cash flows. Most recently, we benefited from the FX hedges put in place to protect the proceeds we expected to receive from the EMEA asset sales, which were denominated in pound sterling and euros. 
With these hedges in place, our U.S. dollar proceeds totaled $882 million but would have been $55 million lower without these hedges. Separately, we also hedged approximately 50% of the EMEA revenues in cash flow as we continue to integrate and business, will increase our revenue and net cash flow hedge position. 
Turning to the second quarter. As depicted on Slide 5, owned Q2 revenues were $900.5 million, the first time we've achieved this milestone level. Revenues were up 3% over the prior quarter and 15% over the same quarter last year on an organic and constant-currency basis. Our global platform continues to expand with Asia Pacific and EMEA showing organic and constant currency growth over the same quarter last year of 21% and 15% respectively, while the Americas region produced steady growth of 12%. 
Our as-reported revenues include $144.5 million from acquisition, consistent with our expectation. Q2 revenue, net of FX hedges, included a $15.5 million positive currency benefit when compared to the average FX rate used last quarter and a $2 million positive benefit when compared to our FX guidance range. 
Total adjusted EBITDA was $420.3 million, up 5% over the prior quarter and 18% over the same quarter last year on an organic and constant-currency basis, above our expectations for strong revenue flow-through and lower-than-expected utility and integration costs. Our as-reported adjusted EBITDA includes $64 million of contribution from our acquisition and $10 million of integration costs. 
Our adjusted EBITDA margin was 46.7%, a 160 basis point increase over the prior quarter. Our Q2 adjusted EBITDA performance, net of our FX hedges, reflects a positive $8.7 million currency benefit when compared to the average FX rates used last quarter and a $1.3 million positive benefit when compared to our FX guidance rate. 
Global AFFO was $290.5 million, a 38% increase over the prior quarter and increased 69% [ph] -- sorry, and increased to 69% of our adjusted EBITDA. Excluding integration costs, the AFFO on a normalized and constant-currency basis increased 7% over the prior quarter, largely due to a strong business performance and lower-than-expected interest expense.
AFFO per share on a fully diluted basis was $4.04 for Q2. If we exclude integration costs, $4.18 on a per-share basis. After we posted our original earnings deck today, please note that we have reissued our earnings deck and posted a new deck that will include AFFO per share data.
Moving to churn. Global MRR churn for Q2 was 1.8%, better than our expectations. We expect the MRR churn for the second half of 2016 to remain in our targeted range of 2% to 2.5% per quarter. And as mentioned at the Analyst Day in June, we continue to expect 2017 MRR churn now average 2% to 2.5% per quarter, which includes the elevated churn in Q1 2017 related to the final phase of Lincoln's bifurcation strategy.
I've said before, MRR churn be lumpy and is a perfect example of it. Although the length in churn will increase in both our cabinet and MRR dollar churn, we expect our MRR per cabinet yields to increase at the same point in time, reflective of Lincoln's per cabinet yield being significant below the Americas MRR per cabinet average. 
Now I'd like to provide a few highlights on the regions. These full results are covered on Slides 6 through 8. The Americas region had another strong revenue quarter, with particularly strength coming from the Brazilian business. The region's MRR per cabinet yield benefited from continued interconnection growth and lower-than-planned MRR churn. Also, the region had higher-than-expected adjusted EBITDA, largely due to the lower-than-expected utility expenses. 
EMEA delivered another solid quarter of revenues, with particular strength in our Dutch market. EMEA continued to execute against these key business initiatives, including the integration of the Telecity business. 
Asia Pacific remains our fastest-growing region with strong bookings in our Tokyo- and Sydney-based market, driven by network and IT verticals. Interconnection revenues continued to face overall growth of the business with the Americas, APAC and EMEA interconnection revenues now at 23%, 13% and 8%, respectively, of recurring revenues. 
Now looking at the balance sheet Steve referred on Slide 9. Unrestricted cash and investments increased over $1 billion after taking into consideration the proceeds related to the EMEA asset sale as well as funds used to purchase to Paris 2 and 3 assets. 
Again, as mentioned during the Analyst Day, although our business plan remains fully funded, including the partial drawdown of our revolving line of credit, we do expect to fully consume the cash in our balance sheet as we continue to invest in scaling our organic with capital expansion initiatives as well as returning capital to our shareholders through our quarterly cash dividend payout. 
Finally, we settled the remaining portion of our June -- the remaining portion of our June '16 convertible debt instrument and capital with a net 1.6 million of shares issued. Our pro forma net leverage stepped down to 3.5x at Q2 annualized adjusted EBITDA, largely due to cash received from the EMEA asset sales, bringing us back into our targeted net leverage range of 3x to 4x adjusted EBITDA. 
Now switching to AFFO and dividends on Slide 10. For 2016, we're raising our as-reported AFFO to now range between $1.04 billion and $1.05 billion, a 26% year-over-year increase, the results of strong operating performance and lower-than-planned interest expense. 
Our normalized and constant currency AFFO is expected to now range between $1.159 billion and 1. [ph] -- pardon me, we'll start again. $1.159 billion and $1.169 billion or a 32% increase over the prior year. Normalizing for integration costs and the Telecity FX translation loss in Q1, our 2016 fully diluted AFFO per share is expected to increase 11% year-over-year to $16.21 using a weighted average of 71.7 million common shares outstanding as presented on Page 32 of our earnings deck. 
Also today, we announced our Q3 dividend of $1.75 a share, consistent with our Q2 quarterly dividend. Our AFFO payout ratio is estimated to be 48% for 2016. 
Now looking at capital expenditures. Please refer to Slide 11. For the quarter, CapEx [indiscernible] $250 million [ph] including a recurring CapEx of $32 million, below our guidance expectations due to timing of cash payments to our contractors. Given our high utilization rate of 82% as well as the strong development of returns across our new expansion and stabilized IBXs, we continue to invest in many of our key markets, with 19 in-progress build, dates expected to open by the end of this year. 
As a result, we expect to spend between $950 million and $1 billion of CapEx in 2016. As the new build, we've opened Sydney 4 earlier this month, our 146th data center and our fifth in the Australian market. As far as scale facility, we'll provide 3,000 cabinets of colocation space when fully built out, effectively doubling our existing capacity in Sydney. 
And finally, we've provided you a number of slides that bridge our 2016 guidance from the normalized 2015 performance, including slides for revenue, adjusted EBITDA and AFFO. Please refer to Slides 12 through 16. I'll now turn the call back to Steve.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Keith, thanks. And finally on Slide 16, which summarizes our updated Q3 and full year 2016 guidance, including the impact of FX changes. Now let me cover our updated 2016 outlook. For the full year of 2016, we're raising our revenue guidance to no
componenttext:
Okay, Keith, thanks. And finally on Slide 16, which summarizes our updated Q3 and full year 2016 guidance, including the impact of FX changes. 
Now let me cover our updated 2016 outlook. For the full year of 2016, we're raising our revenue guidance to now range between $3.598 billion and $3.608 billion, a 32% as-reported growth organic and constant-currency growth rate of 13.8% compared to the prior year. This $8 million revenue increase includes a positive $2 million FX benefit when compared to prior guidance rates. 
Net of adjustments for Paris 2 and 3 acquisition and Bit-isle divestitures, revenue is stepping up $3 million, the result of our strong Q2 performance. For 2016, we are raising our adjusted EBITDA guidance to now range between $1.658 billion and $1.668 billion, a 31% as-reported increase for organic and constant-currency growth rate of 16.8% compared to the prior year. This $13 million adjusted EBITDA increase includes a positive $1 million FX benefit when compared to prior guidance rates. Net of adjustments for the Paris 2 and 3 acquisition and Bit-isle divestitures, adjusted EBITDA is stepping up $8 million, the result of our strong Q2 operating performance. 
And the growth of our business is driving increased adjusted funds from operations corporate cash flows and ultimately, dividend. We're now raising our AFFO to range between $1.04 billion and $1.05 billion, a 32% normalized and constant-currency growth rate compared to the prior year. This $30 million AFFO increase has negligible foreign currency benefits when compared to prior guidance. 
And finally, we are narrowing our 2016 capital expenditures to now range between $950 million and $1 billion for the year. 
So in closing, we continue to achieve above-market growth rates while reinforcing and extending our differentiated market position. We are capturing the significant shift to the cloud, executing well to capture the enterprise and continuing to invest across the business. The benefit our interconnect drive a growing business that will continue to increase our revenues, AFFO, cash flow and dividend. So let me stop here and we'll open it up for questions. I'll turn it back over to you, Sam.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, Jon, we talked a lot about the interconnection-oriented architecture and how far it becomes relevant on how people are architecting their IT. And that's definitely filling up in terms of how people are adding interconnection both in terms of
componenttext: And I guess, Jon, we talked a lot about the interconnection-oriented architecture and how far it becomes relevant on how people are architecting their IT. And that's definitely filling up in terms of how people are adding interconnection both in terms of cross connects as well as greater leverage in our other interconnection-oriented services like Metro Connect, et cetera. So we're adding nice interconnection revenue. And then of course, we are seeing interconnection -- I'm sorry, power densities increase on average. And we have quite a unique advantage in that we have a very large number of customers across a range of power densities, which allows us to continue to extract underutilized power and use it to our economic advantage. So we see both of those factors continue to drive very healthy performance on stabilized IBXs.

componenttext: Yes, very much both. We definitely have -- it was our strongest quarter of performance hub deployment, and that was both in terms of new logo capture both on the enterprise side as well as a number of service provider categories who are effectively using performance hub to optimize our network architectures. And we are seeing a very strong land and expand sort of behavior in the performance hub. So people are typically initially come on the with 1, 2, 3 Performance Hub locations prove out the benefits of those in terms of performance and cost savings relatively quickly to add locations after the validated benefits. So we see both of those and continue to be very excited about that offering in the market.

componenttextpreview: Yes. The Brexit impact is, at this point, very early. I think everybody's waiting the regulatory changes. And as you guys know, typically in the past, any regulatory changes benefited Equinix. So it's too early for us to turn. And we certainly haven't see
componenttext: Yes. The Brexit impact is, at this point, very early. I think everybody's waiting the regulatory changes. And as you guys know, typically in the past, any regulatory changes benefited Equinix. So it's too early for us to turn. And we certainly haven't seen it in our bookings or our pipeline yet. There's a lot of uncertainty around the regulations. And I think we're watching the market very closely as everyone else is. We've not made any changes in our guidance reflective of Brexit at all, but we're continuing to see financial services deals closing in the quarter particularly in the U.K. and EMEA. Generally, the secular trends are unchanged so we see in this part of the world. I think the regulatory thing has to unfold as I said.

Location is a big factor in and its requirements we're seeing driven by The cloud. Most customers we're dealing with are trying to get access to the multi-cloud. So we are able to facilitate that and then there's a lot of data-driven needs and requirements around compliance and customer insight. That's all the typical things that Charles talked about earlier or architecture is driving requirements and we are well-positioned to address any of those and that's underpinning a lot of this interconnection growth.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guess, you've heard us talk a lot over the last several years about that putting the right customers in of the right application and the right assets. And that fundamentally, good execution and discipline against that strategy is what has driven our yield
componenttext: Guess, you've heard us talk a lot over the last several years about that putting the right customers in of the right application and the right assets. And that fundamentally, good execution and discipline against that strategy is what has driven our yield, continue to drive our yield up. So we're really targeting workloads that tend to be interconnection oriented or what disciplined in terms of finding that sweet spot of implementation size that really works well for the business and deliver strong value to the customer. They're typically adding both cross connects in terms of getting direct connectivity to pure play public cloud and then as they expand, their commitment to hybrid cloud and the use of SaaS players really looking at using easy access as a very convenient multi-cloud platform. And so we are seeing a lot about interest end up take on of those even though I think relatively early days in the overall transformation. But that continues to show up in our results from the yield.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's real now in terms of what we are seeing some pretty sizable major IoT players who are their platform inside of Equinix for a variety of reasons, primarily around the effectiveness of them to do aggregation cost effectively and with performanc
componenttext: I think it's real now in terms of what we are seeing some pretty sizable major IoT players who are their platform inside of Equinix for a variety of reasons, primarily around the effectiveness of them to do aggregation cost effectively and with performance inside of our facilities. And so we're definitely seeing those early players come in and use of Platform Equinix. So we think there is a real contribution, but obviously, we are very early stages in I think it's going to continue to play out. We have a number of sort of emerging ecosystems. We have targeted business development efforts that make a very concerted effort to sit down and talk about who we think could come oddments are going to be deployed business development, go out and engage with those players, optimize closed exchange to enable integration with those services and really begin to see the clustering and curating of those ecosystems of that to be have done in the past with others. So still early days but very positive signs and I think it's already contributing but just the tip of the iceberg.

componenttext: I guess, Keith, I'd love to get a little help on guidance. There's a lot of moving parts here, and I just wanted to understand a few things and maybe you could tell me how they all fit together. Maybe the intersection of that and sort of the organic growth expectations for the year. They moved up 40 basis points. But still when I looked at in the first half of the year, you had 16% in the first quarter and 15% organic growth in the second quarter and so just trying to figure out all those things together.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great, Jonathan. So let me start by taking to revenue to the highest level. As you know, we revised our guidance up by a net $8 million. 50% of that $8 million really comes from the acquisition of the Paris 2, 3 assets that will add roughly $4 milli
componenttext: Okay, great, Jonathan. So let me start by taking to revenue to the highest level. As you know, we revised our guidance up by a net $8 million. 50% of that $8 million really comes from the acquisition of the Paris 2, 3 assets that will add roughly $4 million of revenue to the second half of the year. For all intents and purposes, the FX and the divestiture that we referred to, Bit-isle they offset each other so we have a little bit of a positive currency benefit, offset by a lost of divestitures. So that really is leaving 50% of $4 million of value to the performance in our Q2 results. So to that, that gives you a 50% year-over-year growth rate on an organic basis. As we look at the acquisition so both Bit-isle and Telecity, they're performing against our expectations. As you've heard us say before, there's a lot of friction as included the Telecity transaction and then sold off a number of the assets. Were no looking forward the focus of that business and I would expect that to see the momentum of pickup in Telecity. As with the beta, us referred to, that was embedded in the business and yes we are experiencing the churn that the teams are continuing to perform well. And so in both cases, when we combine a look at the acquisitions, they are performing to our expectations. The last thing I'll say is one of the things that is probably -- let me say 2 things. One thing that is clearly evident is as we think about our booking expectations, we deliver almost exactly what we expected for the quarter-end so it is very consistent with performance relative to what we are seeing in the prior quarters from a gross and net bookings perspective. With that all said, there is been a positive increase of backlog because as we think about the complexity of the global cloud implementation, they are expanding the book to bill and to give you size our order of magnitude of the $4 million of delayed revenue associated with increased backlog primitive to our book to bill word. So that would be the second to the last comment. And the last comment I'll make is the recurring initial question, nonrecurring we saw a little bit of an uptick this quarter over and above what we originally anticipated but we still have -- our underlaying assumption is nonrecurring revenue will revert closer to 5% as we scale through the year except if there's any change on that we will certainly guide through but that is the assumption that we made in of the Q3 -- sorry, the updated revenue guidance.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to today's conference call. Before we get started, I'd like to remind everyone that some of the statements we'll be making today are forward looking in nature and involve risks and uncertainties. Actual results may v
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to today's conference call. Before we get started, I'd like to remind everyone that some of the statements we'll be making today are forward looking in nature and involve risks and uncertainties. Actual results may vary significantly from those statements and may be affected by the risks we identified in today's press release and those identified in our filings with the SEC, including our most recent Form 10-K filed on February 26, 2016, and 10-Q filed on May 9, 2016. 
Equinix assumes no obligation and does not intend to update or comment on forward-looking statements made on this call.
In addition, in light of Regulation Fair Disclosure, it's Equinix' policy not to comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it is done through an explicit public disclosure. In addition, we'll provide non-GAAP measures on today's conference call. We provide a reconciliation of those measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures and a list of the reasons why the company uses these measures in today's press release on the Equinix Investor Relations page at www.equinix.com.
We'd also like to remind you that we post important information about Equinix on the Investor Relations page of our website. We encourage you to check our website regularly for the most current available information. 
With us today are Steve Smith, Equinix' CEO and President; Keith Taylor, Chief Financial Officer; and Charles Meyers, Chief Operating Officer. Following our prepared remarks, we'll be taking questions from sell-side analysts. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'll turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Katrina, and good afternoon, and welcome to our second quarter earnings call. We had a great first half of 2016, delivering both revenues and adjusted EBITDA above the top end of our guidance range as our global scale and reach, strength of
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Katrina, and good afternoon, and welcome to our second quarter earnings call. We had a great first half of 2016, delivering both revenues and adjusted EBITDA above the top end of our guidance range as our global scale and reach, strength of our digital ecosystems and service excellence continue to drive profitable growth. 
As depicted on Slide 3 of our presentation, second quarter revenues were $900.5 million, up 3% quarter-over-quarter and up 15% over the same quarter last year on an organic and constant-currency basis. Adjusted EBITDA was $420.3 million for the quarter, up 5% over the prior quarter and up 18% year-over-year on an organic and constant-currency basis. This drove AFFO growth of 37% year-over-year on a normalized and constant-currency basis. 
We delivered strong growth in net bookings, with increasing contribution from our indirect channel. Our key operating metrics continue to be very healthy with firm MRR per cabinet, low churn and strong growth in both billable cabinet and interconnection. We continue to progress against key operational and business objectives in 2016 to grow our market position globally, centering on successful acquisition integration, sustained organic development and scaling our interconnection services. So let me provide some commentary in each of these in turn. 
Starting with acquisition. We are focusing our energy on successfully integrating Telecity and Bit-isle, scaling the business to drive even more value for our customers and enhancing our cloud and network density across EMEA and Asia. We've delivered against key integration goals and milestones and are pleased with the progress we have made in the first half. 
The Telecity business delivered solid financial performance despite normal integration challenges and complexity associated with the divestitures, and we are seeing value creation across a broad range of synergy category. Our EMEA sales force has been fully integrated, and our cross-selling program is tracking ahead of plan, with particular customer interest in the overlapping markets of London and Amsterdam and our new markets in Stockholm and Manchester. 
The financial and IT systems work is well under way, and we've defined the critical initiatives to operationally integrate our back op. We have completed the first large systems conversion with the Telecity Dutch business now operating within the Equinix corporate systems and processes and plan to migrate the remaining countries through 2017. 
In early July, we also completed the sale of 8 European assets for $882 million updated for FX, as required by the European Commission as part of its approval of our purchase of TelecityGroup. Completing this last milestone in the acquisition process paves the way for us to fully focus on selling our new combined European platform. 
We're also pleased with Bit-isle's progress, and the market reaction to the acquisition has been positive. The business is performing well, with cross-selling momentum accelerating including several wins with Japanese multinationals that are leveraging space and connectivity across existing and acquired sites. We are further optimizing this business by divesting 2 small non-core businesses, which we completed in the first half of 2016. We also expect to divest Terra Power, a collection of solar power assets, in the second half of this year. 
Turning to our organic development activity. We continue to invest in expanding globally. Allocating 95% of our expansion capital to building off-campus or existing market build for a deep knowledge of fill rate, pipeline and competitive supply leads to higher returns. We now have 19 announced expansion projects under way. In this quarter, we are moving forward with additional expansions in Ashburn, Frankfurt, Paris and Singapore, totaling over $250 million of capital expenditures. 
We are starting work on DC12, the first data center build in our Ashburn North Campus in Northern Virginia, which is on 44 acres of owned, undeveloped land next to our current Ashburn campus. Today, Ashburn is one of our major campuses with over 14,000 cabinets across 10 IBXs, and it's the largest Internet exchange point in North America. The new Ashburn North Campus, which we plan to develop over the next few years, will expand our asset ownership and effectively double our capacity in this important market. 
Turning to Frankfurt. We see continued demand in this vibrant market coming from Internet and cloud providers due to data sovereignty compliance as well as financial services growth. We are building Frankfurt 6, a new IBX located on owned land next to Frankfurt 4 and tethered to our core network hub in this market. 
These capital investments are delivering very healthy growth and strong returns as shown on Slide 4. Revenues from our 70 stabilized IBXs grew 8% year-over-year, above our historical trend line and largely driven by an increase in cross-connect and power density. We continue to find ways to optimize our asset base, putting the right customer and application into the right asset, which drives a firm yield per cabinet. These stabilized assets are generating a 32% cash-on-cash return on the gross PP&E invested, and utilization remains at a stable 86%. 
In terms of our asset ownership strategy, our goal is to produce over 50% from owned properties over time by developing land such as in Silicon Valley and Ashburn as well as purchasing additional site as it makes economic and strategic sense. Consistent with this strategy, we purchased our Paris 2 and 3 IBXs for $211 million from Digital Realty, which closed this week. 
Over 70 carriers reside in Paris 2 and 3. They're in the most densely connected data center campus in France. Ownership will enable us to achieve better operating costs, enhanced customer service and further expand this campus over time. The acquisition of Paris 2 and 3 is an example of where we can acquire assets and operate the property more efficiently for our own purpose, thereby allowing us to enjoy a higher return. With this purchase, 35% of our revenues now come from owned assets. 
Turning to interconnection. The need to build next-generation IT architectures that connect network, cloud, people and data continues to drive customer demand for interconnection. We now have 183,000 cross-connects, and interconnection revenue grew 21% year-over-year on an organic and constant-currency basis. 
Interconnection revenues represent 16% of our global recurring revenues, and this is the eighth quarter in a row where we had a greater than 5,000 cross-connects. We saw a particularly strong growth in connections to cloud providers, with accelerated additions of participants, ports and virtual circuit on our market-leading Cloud Exchange platform and strong sales of cross-connect to facilitate Direct Connect into pure-play cloud. 
Our Internet exchange continues to scale with 5.6 terabits of peak traffic, growing over 35% year-over-year as network and cloud providers upgrade their capacity and transition to 100 GB equipment. The transition to cloud continues to unfold as enterprises are re-architecting IT to drive down costs, improve performance and leverage clouds and network. 
We continue to see growth in Fortune 500 new customer and expansion wins as the explosion of data and devices are transforming how large multinationals architect their infrastructure, leveraging interconnection as a core design principle. We added 7 new Fortune 500 customers in the quarter such as Ticketmaster, an online ticket vendor, leveraging Equinix to improve digital experience and integrate cloud infrastructure. We now have over 150 of the Fortune 500 customers and over 500 of the Global 2000. 
Now let me cover quarterly highlights from our industry vertical, starting with the network. This vertical experienced strong bookings, led by strength in Asia as wireline providers including Telstra, SingTel and Softbank expanded with multi-region deployment. We saw growth with regional Internet service providers including U.S. Internet Corp., a regional ISP peering to support growing enterprise cloud demand; and GCI, a regional telecom provider adding cloud connectivity capabilities via our Cloud Exchange to augment their network service offering. 
Additionally, our strength as a global platform allows us to target strategic subsea cable projects to land within our ecosystem hub, and we are seeing pipeline and activity build in this growing segment including 2 new wins this quarter. Equinix is the biggest aggregator of digital ecosystems, making us the most logical choice for subsea cable operators to get the immediate benefit tapping into a mature ecosystem of buyers. 
The financial services vertical experienced continued expansion into our core electronic trading ecosystem as well as diversification into other subsegments. This quarter, we saw additional expansions from investment banks such as Morgan Stanley, better leveraging Equinix for critical data center, network and cloud connectivity. We are also observing the beginning of clustering of electronic payment counterparties across regions, including the addition of Merchant Customer Exchange, a leading merchant payment system that is deployed to peer traffic and connect to multiple clouds. 
In the content digital media vertical, advertisers and digital media were the growth drivers for booking. Asia delivered strong bookings this quarter, reflecting digital adoption in the region. Customer wins included Index Exchange, a premier ad tech firm, leveraging Ad-IX; and Taboola, a content discovery platform, optimizing performance at the edge to better serve the APAC region. 
The cloud and IT services vertical is the second fastest-growing vertical driven by cloud hyperscalers continue to deploy access nodes globally as well strategic wins with leading SaaS providers. Our traction in the Software-as-a-Service space is enhancing the value of our platform to enterprise clients. We are also observing a maturity cycle where many SaaS providers launched in the public cloud then transition to hybrid cloud as they scale and service a wider customer base. We had a great quarter for cloud services adoption, with over 460 enterprises, clouds, IT service providers and networks now interconnecting on our Cloud Exchange. 
Turning to the enterprise. This vertical continues to be the fastest-growing vertical, with a record number of Performance Hub deployments this quarter. Wins included a Fortune 100 manufacturer that is re-architecting by building edge node at Equinix and a U.S. federal agency providing delivery services that is deploying multiple Performance Hubs and integrating multiple clouds on our platform. 
Today, over 470 customers have deployed our Performance Hub solution, which helps enterprises optimize their network architectures, access the cloud and drive application performance. Updated for acquisition, cloud and IT services and enterprise verticals now represent 29% and 14% of our revenues, respectively, and we continue to expect these verticals to lead growth as we progress with enterprise cloud adoption. 
And finally, we are seeing solid progress in our channel and partner programs as a percentage of our bookings coming from channel has increased from high single digits 3 years ago to over 15% today. Our channel strategy leverages a range of partner types, each playing a critical role in scaling our enterprise [indiscernible]. 
Platform partners help us leverage mind share and awareness with high-value target customers committed to hybrid cloud as the IT architecture of choice. Referral partners create leverage in our lead-generation engine, and resellers magnify our sales effort and combine key value-added services with Equinix offers to deliver complete solutions that more directly address the integrated needs of enterprise customers. 
By coordinating our sales activity with key partners at the local level, we've been able to meaningfully expand our market reach and have seen our channel program as our most prolific source of new logos for the past several quarters. 
So let me stop here and turn it over to Keith to cover some of the results for the quarter.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon to everyone on the call. It's great to be able to update you on our second quarter performance, our 54th quarter of top line revenue growth. By almost any measure, this was another strong quarter for Equinix. For the
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon to everyone on the call. It's great to be able to update you on our second quarter performance, our 54th quarter of top line revenue growth. By almost any measure, this was another strong quarter for Equinix. 
For the first half of 2016, we delivered results better than our expectations and created value for our investors by scaling revenues while improving margins, resulting in meaningful flow-through to adjusted EBITDA and AFFO, with an absolute dollar terms as well as on a per-share basis. 
The organic business continues to perform well, and our acquisitions are delivering against our expectations. Also the number of cross-sell successes and of the depth of the sales pipeline continues to grow. Overall, we're delighted with the progress of our integration efforts related to both Bit-isle and Telecity. 
Dell has have moved up the margin curve faster than expected despite our anticipated higher churn levels, and we've optimized the business more quickly than originally planned. As Steve noted, we now expect to sell non-core Bit-isle business lines prior to the end of the year. This allows us to focus on the higher-value colocation and interconnection offerings, along with some manual [ph] services in support of the local Tokyo market. 
With regard to Telecity, now that the divestiture process is complete, the team is highly focused on integrating the former Telecity businesses into Equinix as quickly as possible. In July, we fully integrated the Dutch business, which is now operating within our systems and processes. This will soon be followed by the U.K., Irish and Swedish businesses over the next few quarters. 
With regards to our key operating metrics, as highlighted by Steve yet worth mentioning again, our MRR per cabinet yield remains firm at just over $2,000 per cabinet, up $18 on a constant-currency basis over the prior quarter, with particular strength in the Americas region. Also, we added 3,300 net billable cabinets for the quarter, effectively returning to our normal add level. And the MRR churn was lower than expected. 
With respect to our interconnection offerings, net cross-connect addition remains very positive, adding another 6,100 in the quarter. Also, the provision capacity and traffic growth on our Internet exchanges has substantially outpaced our competitors, partially reflected by the meaningful increase in the number of 100 GB ports provisioned on our exchanges. As we measure the health and success of our exchanges, we now will report provision capacity in addition to the total port count to highlight the momentum we're seeing in the interconnection offering. 
Now I'd like to add a few comments on foreign currency movements in the quarter. The U.S. dollar weakened during the back half of Q1 through most of Q2 against many of our operating currency. This resulted in a meaningful FX benefit for the second quarter relative to Q1. However, following the Brexit announcement on June 24, the U.S. dollar strengthened significantly against the British pound and the euro. Despite these FX movements, we expect no significant change in either our 2016 revenue or adjusted EBITDA guidance related to FX movement as many of the other operating currencies that we operate in strengthened against the U.S. dollar in Q2.
Now we continue to place currency hedges into our business to reduce financial volatility and protect certainty of our cash flows. Most recently, we benefited from the FX hedges put in place to protect the proceeds we expected to receive from the EMEA asset sale, which was denominated in pound sterling and euros. With these hedges in place, our U.S. dollar proceeds totaled $882 million but would have been $55 million lower without these hedges. Separately, we also hedged approximately 50% of the EMEA revenues and cash flows. As we continue to integrate Telecity into our EMEA business, we'll increase our revenue and net cash flow hedge position. 
So turning to the second quarter. As depicted on Slide 5, global Q2 revenues were $900.5 million, the first time we've achieved this milestone level. Revenues were up 3% over the prior quarter and 15% over the same quarter last year on an organic and constant-currency basis. Our global platform continues to expand, with Asia Pacific and EMEA showing organic and constant-currency growth over the same quarter last year of 21% and 15%, respectively, while the Americas region produced steady growth of 12%. 
Our as-reported revenues include $144.5 million from acquisitions, consistent with our expectation. Q2 revenue, net of FX hedges, included a $15.5 million positive currency benefit when compared to the average FX rate used last quarter and a $2 million positive benefit when compared to our FX guidance range. 
Global adjusted EBITDA was $420.3 million, up 5% over the prior quarter and 18% over the same quarter last year on an organic and constant-currency basis, above our expectations with a strong revenue flow-through and lower-than-expected utility and integration costs. Our as-reported adjusted EBITDA includes $64 million of contribution from our acquisition and $10 million of integration costs. 
Our adjusted EBITDA margin was 46.7%, a 160 basis point increase over the prior quarter. Our Q2 adjusted EBITDA performance, net of our FX hedges, reflects a positive $8.7 million currency benefit when compared to the average FX rate used last quarter and a $1.3 million positive benefit when compared to our FX guidance rate. 
Global AFFO was $290.5 million, a 38% increase over the prior quarter and increased 69% -- for an increase to 69% of our adjusted EBITDA. Excluding integration costs, the AFFO on a normalized and constant-currency basis increased 7% over the prior quarter largely due to a strong business performance and lower-than-expected interest expense.
AFFO per share on a fully diluted basis was $4.04 for Q2, but if you exclude integration costs, $4.18 on a per-share basis. After we posted our original earnings deck today, please note that we have reissued our earnings deck and posted a new deck that will include AFFO per-share data.
Moving to churn. Global MRR churn for Q2 was 1.8%, better than our expectations. We expect the MRR churn for the second half of 2016 to remain in our targeted range of 2% to 2.5% per quarter. And as mentioned at the Analyst Day in June, we continue to expect 2017 MRR churn to average 2% to 2.5% per quarter, which includes the elevated churn in Q1 2017 related to the final phase of LinkedIn's bifurcation strategy.
I've said before, MRR churn be lumpy and the LinkedIn churn is a perfect example of this. Although the LinkedIn churn will create an increase in both our cabinet and MRR dollar churn, we expect our MRR per cabinet yields to increase at the same point in time, reflective of LinkedIn's per cabinet yield being significantly below the Americas MRR per cabinet average. 
Now I'd like to provide a few highlights on the regions. These full results are covered on Slides 6 through 8. The Americas region had another strong revenue quarter, with particularly strength coming from the Brazilian business. The region's MRR per cabinet yield benefited from continued interconnection growth and lower-than-planned MRR churn. Also, the region had higher-than-expected adjusted EBITDA, largely due to the lower-than-expected utility expenses. 
EMEA delivered another solid quarter of revenues, with particular strength in our Dutch market. EMEA continued to execute against these key business initiatives, including the integration of the Telecity business. 
Asia Pacific remains our fastest-growing region, with strong bookings in our Tokyo- and Sydney-based markets, driven by network and cloud and IT verticals. 
Interconnection revenues continued to outpace overall growth of the business, with the Americas, APAC and EMEA interconnection revenues now at 23%, 13% and 8%, respectively, of recurring revenues. 
Now looking at the balance sheet. Please refer to Slide 9. Unrestricted cash and investments increased to over $1 billion after taking into consideration the proceeds related to the EMEA asset sale as well as funds used to purchase our Paris 2 and 3 assets. 
Again, as mentioned during the Analyst Day, although our business plan remains fully funded, including the partial drawdown of our revolving line of credit, we do expect to fully consume the cash in our balance sheet as we continue to invest in scaling our organic business with capital expansion initiatives as well as returning capital to our shareholders through our quarterly cash dividend payout. 
Finally, we settled the remaining portion of our June -- the remaining portion of our June '16 convertible debt instrument and capital with a net 1.6 million of shares issued. Our pro forma net leverage stepped down to 3.5x our Q2 annualized adjusted EBITDA, largely due to cash received from the EMEA asset sales, bringing us back into our targeted net leverage range of 3 to 4x adjusted EBITDA. 
Now switching to AFFO and dividends on Slide 10. For 2016, we're raising our as-reported AFFO to now range between $1.04 billion and $1.05 billion, a 26% year-over-year increase, the results of strong operating performance and lower-than-planned interest expense. 
Our normalized and constant-currency AFFO is expected to now range between 1.15 -- sorry, $1.159 billion and 1 point -- pardon me, we'll start again. $1.159 billion and $1.169 billion or a 32% increase over the prior year. Normalizing for integration costs and the Telecity FX translation loss in Q1, our 2016 fully diluted AFFO per share is expected to increase 11% year-over-year to $16.21 using on a weighted average 71.7 million common shares outstanding as presented on Page 32 of our earnings deck. 
Also today, we announced our Q3 dividend of $1.75 a share, consistent with our Q2 quarterly dividend. Our AFFO payout ratio is estimated to be 48% for 2016. 
Now looking at CapEx. Please refer to Slide 11. For the quarter, capital expenditures were $250 million, including a recurring CapEx of $32 million, below our guidance expectations due to timing of cash payments to our contractors. Given our currently high utilization rate of 82% as well as the strong development of returns across our new expansion and stabilized IBXs, we continue to invest in many of our key markets with 19 in-progress build, 8 of which are expected to open by the end of this year. As a result, we expect to spend between $950 million and $1 billion of CapEx in 2016. 
As regard [ph] the new build, we've opened Sydney 4 earlier this month, our 146th data center and our fifth in the Australian market. This large-scale facility will provide 3,000 cabinets of colocation space when fully built out, effectively doubling our existing capacity in Sydney. 
And finally, we've provided you a number of slides that bridge our 2016 guidance from the normalized 2015 performance, including slides for revenue, adjusted EBITDA and AFFO. Please refer to Slides 12 through 16. 
I'll now turn the call back to Steve.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Keith, thanks. And finally, on Slide 16, which summarizes our updated Q3 and full year 2016 guidance, including the impact of FX changes. Now let me cover our updated 2016 outlook. For the full year of 2016, we're raising our revenue guidance to n
componenttext:
Okay. Keith, thanks. And finally, on Slide 16, which summarizes our updated Q3 and full year 2016 guidance, including the impact of FX changes. 
Now let me cover our updated 2016 outlook. For the full year of 2016, we're raising our revenue guidance to now range between $3.598 billion and $3.608 billion, a 32% as-reported growth for organic and constant-currency growth rate of 13.8% compared to the prior year. This $8 million revenue increase includes a positive $2 million FX benefit when compared to prior guidance rate.
Net of adjustments for Paris 2 and 3 acquisition and Bit-isle divestitures, revenue is stepping up $3 million, the result of our strong Q2 performance. For 2016, we are raising our adjusted EBITDA guidance to now range between $1.658 billion and $1.668 billion, a 31% as-reported increase for organic and constant-currency growth rate of 16.8% compared to the prior year. This $13 million adjusted EBITDA increase includes a positive $1 million FX benefit when compared to prior guidance rate. Net of adjustments for the Paris 2 and 3 acquisition and Bit-isle divestitures, adjusted EBITDA is stepping up $8 million, the result of our strong Q2 operating performance. 
And the growth of our business is driving increased adjusted funds from operations, which drives corporate cash flows and ultimately, dividend. We're now raising our AFFO to range between $1.04 billion and $1.05 billion, a 32% normalized and constant-currency growth rate compared to the prior year. This $30 million AFFO increase has negligible foreign currency benefits when compared to prior guidance. And finally, we are narrowing our 2016 capital expenditures to now range between $950 million and $1 billion for the year. 
So in closing, we continue to achieve above-market growth rates while reinforcing and extending our differentiated market position. We are capturing the significant shift to the cloud, executing well to capture the enterprise and continuing to invest across the business. The benefits of our interconnection strategy drive a growing and durable business that will continue to increase our revenues, AFFO, cash flow and dividend. 
So let me stop here, and we'll open it up for questions. I'll turn it back over to you, Sam.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

You mentioned power entity and cross-connects. So are there any regions or metros where you're seeing that more than others?

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jon, I'll take that one. As we think about that number, number one is 8%, as we said year-over-year growth and 9% on a constant-currency basis, what we're seeing continued growth -- part of the metrics that we provided you today were certainly provision f
componenttext: Jon, I'll take that one. As we think about that number, number one is 8%, as we said year-over-year growth and 9% on a constant-currency basis, what we're seeing continued growth -- part of the metrics that we provided you today were certainly provision for growth cross-connects but also just giving you a sense of the momentum on an MRR per cabinet basis. So a lot of that's attributed to, again, power and interconnection revenue. As a result, no matter where you look across our portfolio, in all 3 cases, our MRR per cabinet has moved up and to the right. That's reflective of the performance across all 3 regions. And as a result, you're seeing that benefit really holds true and all stabilized that at each of our markets.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I guess, I might just add that the -- Jon, that we talked a lot about the interconnection-oriented architecture and how that is becoming relevant to how people are architecting their IT. And that's definitely filling up in terms of how people are
componenttext: Yes. And I guess, I might just add that the -- Jon, that we talked a lot about the interconnection-oriented architecture and how that is becoming relevant to how people are architecting their IT. And that's definitely filling up in terms of how people are adding interconnection both in terms of cross-connects as well as greater leverage in our other interconnection-oriented services like Metro Connect, et cetera. So we're adding nice interconnection revenue. And then, of course, we are seeing interconnection -- I'm sorry, power densities increase on average. And we have quite a unique advantage in that we have a very large number of customers across a range of power densities, which allows us to continue to extract underutilized power and use it to our economic advantage. So we see both of those factors, and they continue driving very healthy performance on stabilized IBXs.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On enterprise and performance, I'm sort of interested, you had been successful now for several quarters. And what you are seeing 1 year in from some of those deployments? In other words, is there a consistent trend that you're seeing where those are kind
componenttext: On enterprise and performance, I'm sort of interested, you had been successful now for several quarters. And what you are seeing 1 year in from some of those deployments? In other words, is there a consistent trend that you're seeing where those are kind of stable and a lot of growth is coming from new logos? Or are you seeing these 1-year-olds or older deployments expand either the number of locations or the size of their footprint within existing locations?

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, very much both. We are -- we definitely have -- it was our strongest quarter of Performance Hub deployment, and that was both in terms of new logo capture both on the enterprise side as well as a number of service provider categories who are effectiv
componenttext: Yes, very much both. We are -- we definitely have -- it was our strongest quarter of Performance Hub deployment, and that was both in terms of new logo capture both on the enterprise side as well as a number of service provider categories who are effectively using Performance Hub to optimize our network architectures. And we are seeing a very strong land-and-expand sort of behavior in the Performance Hubs. So people are typically initially come on the with 1, 2, 3 Performance Hub locations prove out the benefits of those in terms of performance and cost savings, and then they circle behind relatively quickly to add locations after the validated benefits. So we see both of those and continue to be very excited about that offering in the market and how it's being received.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'd add on top of that, Jonathan, this is Steve, that -- as I mentioned in the script, we're -- we added 7 Fortune 500 customer wins this quarter and a record number of Performance Hubs, which is exactly tied to what Charles was pointing is that
componenttext: I guess, I'd add on top of that, Jonathan, this is Steve, that -- as I mentioned in the script, we're -- we added 7 Fortune 500 customer wins this quarter and a record number of Performance Hubs, which is exactly tied to what Charles was pointing is that it's now turned to our largest contributor of new customer adds. Inside of that, the manufacturing and professional services segments, inside the enterprise verticals are, in this quarter, where we saw a pretty big uptick of win.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On Europe, just quickly, I wondered if you could share with us some of the feedback that you're maybe seeing from your various partners and customers with regards to Brexit and how that might affect IT spending trends.
componenttext: On Europe, just quickly, I wondered if you could share with us some of the feedback that you're maybe seeing from your various partners and customers with regards to Brexit and how that might affect IT spending trends.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The Brexit impact is, at this point, very early. I think everybody's waiting the regulatory changes. And as you guys know, typically in the past, any regulatory changes have benefited Equinix. So it's too early for us to determine. And we certainly h
componenttext: Yes. The Brexit impact is, at this point, very early. I think everybody's waiting the regulatory changes. And as you guys know, typically in the past, any regulatory changes have benefited Equinix. So it's too early for us to determine. And we certainly haven't seen it in our bookings or our pipeline yet. There's a lot of uncertainty around the regulations, and I think we're watching the market very closely as everyone else is. We've not made any changes in our guidance reflective of Brexit at all, but we're continuing to see financial services deals close in the quarter, particularly in the U.K. and EMEA. Generally, the secular trends are unchanged, so we're still seeing the typical trends that we see in this part of the world. I think the regulatory thing has to unfold as I said.

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Morgan from Canaccord.

componenttext: On the -- just focusing on the domestic side in terms of your MRR per cab up $36 sequentially. I mean, you highlighted cloud cross-connects as one thing, but it sounds like it's just -- it's running ahead of your own expectations. And I'm just wondering if you could drill down into kind of maybe some areas where you think the drivers are really occurring. And then kind of following on that, whether looking at that [ph] change, are you seeing greater acceptance of that product? And then on top of that kind of subsequent add-on, just cross-connects as your customers adopt that?

headline: Equinix, Inc. (REIT), Equinix, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You want me to start, Charles, or...
